[http://lytecmedicalbillingsoftware.com/#medical-billing-and-coding Medical billing and coding] is a great field to get into. All healthcare providers and physicians depend on their [http://lytecmedicalbillingsoftware.com/#medical-billers medical billers] to get reimbursed for the services they provide to their patients. In a way, coders and billers help physicians with their livelihood. Though medical billers do not need a college degree to get a job, they do need extensive training and in some cases certification to get proper training. The better the training, the better the position and the more job security they will have.Medical billing is not what it used to be. Positions in [http://lytecmedicalbillingsoftware.com/#medical-billing-and-coding medical billing] used to consist of extensive hours filling out medical forms and insurance company forms in order to insure that the doctors and medical professionals would get paid properly for the [http://lytecmedicalbillingsoftware.com/#medical-billing-services medical billing service] they provided to their patients. Now in the age of technology, paper claim forms and insurance forms are a thing of the past. [http://lytecmedicalbillingsoftware.com/#medical-billing-software Medical billing software] is the way most health care professionals do their insurance claims. The only paper that is needed to properly file a claim with an insurance company is the paper chart that the doctor has on each of his patients.After the doctor sees his patient and the chart are handed over to the medical biller, [http://lytecmedicalbillingsoftware.com/#medical-billing-software Medical billing software company] helps to properly submit medical forms to the patient's insurance company. When a physician chooses to purchase medical billing software they essentially help their office become more efficient in their procedures.Because of medical billing software, you will find that physician's offices do not necessarily employ their own medical billers and coders, though still there is an option called as [http://lytecmedicalbillingsoftware.com/#medical-billing-from-home Medical billing from home]. Now with the Internet and with all of the insurance billing software out there many companies have been born that do medical coding and billing only. Therefore, doctors' offices have accounts with these medical billing services and submit their information and the company does the insurance billing for them.

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=4]]
==Annotations== ==References== {| style="width: 26%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid #bfb; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Colophon|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/003|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=6]]
==Annotations== '''S'''{{spaces|5}}''Ulysses'' opens and closes with the serpentine letter ''S''. This has been compared to the figures of serpents in the ''[[w:Book of Kells|Book of Kells]]'' that have their tails in their mouths ([[w:ouroboros|ouroboros]]): ''Ulysses'' is a closed circle, ending where it began. In ''[[w:Finnegans Wake|Finnegans Wake]]'' Joyce achieved a similar effect by linking the opening and closing sentences of the book so that the former completes the latter. Joyce was greatly influenced by the ''Book of Kells''. Referring to Edward Sullivan's ''The Book of Kells'' (a facsimile of some pages of the manuscript with a commentary), he once told his young Irish friend Arthur Power: "In all the places I have been to, Rome, Zurich, Trieste, I have taken it about with me, and have pored over its workmanship for hours. It is the most purely Irish thing we have, and some of the big initial letters which swing right across a page have the essential character of a chapter of ''Ulysses''."{{cite book |title=James Joyce |last=Ellmann |first=Richard |year=1982 |publisher=Oxford University Press |location=New York |isbn=0-19-281465-6 |page=545}} '''S'''{{spaces|5}}The three parts into which Joyce divides ''Ulysses'' open with significant letters: :Part I (''The Telemachiad''): '''''S''''' :Part II (''The Odyssey''): '''''M''''' :Part III (''The Nostos''): '''''P''''' These letters are the initials of the novel's three protagonists: ''S''tephen Dedalus, ''M''olly (Marion) Bloom and ''P''oldy (Leopold) Bloom.{{cite book |title=Ulysses Annotated |last=Gifford |first=Don |coauthors=Robert J. Seidman |year=1988 |publisher=University of California Press |location=London |isbn=0-520-05639-6 |page=12}} ''S'', ''M'' and ''P'' are also significant in the context of Aristotelian logic. In a [[w:syllogism|syllogism]] there are three terms: the subject, the middle term and the predicate. These are conventionally represented by the letters ''S'', ''M'' and ''P'' respectively. In the original 1922 edition, Episode 17 (''Ithaca'') ended with a large black period, which was once used as a conventional sign for [[w:Q.E.D.|Q.E.D.]] at the end of a formal proof or demonstration. Thus ''Ulysses'' is a polemical work with a logical structure.Gifford, ''Ibid.'' '''Stately'''{{spaces|5}}For all his cynicism and neo-paganism, Buck Mulligan is identified as an upholder of church and state. '''plump'''{{spaces|5}}(1) Fat, chubby. Joyce's principal model for Buck Mulligan, [[w:Oliver St. John Gogarty|Oliver St. John Gogarty]], was hardly ''plump''. Ellmann writes that when Joyce first met Gogarty in the National Library in 1903, Gogarty was "handsome, lithe though inclined to fat, prosperous and merry."Ellmann, ''op. cit.'' 117. In 1904 Gogarty attended [[w:University of Oxford|Oxford]], where, in his own words, he "became mentally and physically ''pinguis'' [Latin: ''fat'']".{{cite book |title=Many Lines to Thee: Letters to G. K. A. Bell 1904-1907 |last=St John Gogarty |first=Oliver |editor=James F. Carens |year=1971 |publisher=Dolmen |location=Ireland |page=29}} Whether plump is an accurate description of Gogarty, there is no doubt that Joyce intended Buck Mulligan to be fat: in ''Oxen of the Sun'' ([[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Oxen_of_the_Sun/384|384.33-36]]), Dixon jocosely inquires whether Mulligan's "incipient ventripotence" indicates that he is pregnant. It is possible that, in the Shakespearean context of ''Ulysses'', Joyce intended Mulligan to represent the fat knight [[w:Falstaff|Falstaff]] to Stephen's [[w:Prince Hal|Prince Hal]]. '''plump'''{{spaces|5}}(2) Blunt (in manners); crude; rude; clownish.''Oxford English Dictionary.'' These adjectives accurately describe Mulligan's character. '''Buck Mulligan'''{{spaces|5}}Malachi Mulligan is a portrait of Oliver St. John Gogarty, a young writer and medical student with whom Joyce (portrayed here as Stephen Dedalus) lived for six nights (9-14 June 1904) in the [[w:Martello tower|Martello Tower]] at [[w:Sandycove|Sandycove]]. According to the two [[w:Linati schema for Ulysses|schemas]] which Joyce provided for ''Ulysses'', Buck Mulligan here represents [[w:Antinous son of Eupeithes|Antinous]], the leader of the suitors of [[w:Penelope|Penelope]] in the ''[[w:Odyssey|Odyssey]]''. As Stephen represents [[:w:Prince Hamlet|Hamlet]] as well as the ''Odyssey's'' [[w:Telemachus|Telemachus]], Mulligan can also be identified with [[w:King Claudius|Claudius]]. '''stairhead'''{{spaces|5}}A [[wikt:stairhead|stairhead]] is a level space at the top of a flight of steps. In the Martello tower at Sandycove, a narrow spiral staircase of stone steps leads from the interior of the tower to the roof or [[wikt:terreplein|terreplein]]. Buck Mulligan, in mockery of the Catholic ceremony of the [[w:Mass (liturgy)|Mass]], has just ascended these steps in imitation of a Catholic priest ascending the steps to the altar. '''bearing'''{{spaces|5}}A more solemn word than ''carrying''. One also ''[[wikt:bear#Etymology_2|bears arms]]'', appropriate here, as Mulligan and Stephen will [[wikt:cross swords|cross swords]] in this episode. The military setting in the Martello tower underscores the sense or meaning Joyce assigned to this episode in the Linati schema: ''Il figlio spodestato alla lotta'' ("The dispossessed son in combat"). '''bowl'''{{spaces|5}}Mulligan's shaving bowl represents the [[w:chalice|chalice]] that holds the wine, which becomes the blood of Christ in the Mass. '''razor'''{{spaces|5}}The first of many allusions in this episode to blades and cutting. Mulligan is a shaver, and also a future surgeon, but the deadliest weapon in this episode is neither the razor nor the scalpel. Rather than belonging to Mulligan, it is in the possession of Stephen (at least as he sees it). It is ''the lancet'' of his (Stephen's) art, the ''cold steel pen''. This allusion is a play on the phrase "the pen is mightier than the sword". '''''Introibo ad altare Dei'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''I will go in to the altar of God.'' The Latin [[w:Tridentine Mass|Tridentine Mass]] opens with the ''Prayers at the Foot of the Altar''. After making the [[w:Sign of the Cross|Sign of the Cross]], the priest and his servers intone an [[wikt:antiphon|antiphon]] based on Psalm 43 (Vulgate 42), ''Iudica Me, Deus'' (''Judge Me, O God''), the fourth verse of which Mulligan quotes. By intoning these words ''after'' he has ascended the steps, Mulligan has perverted the order of the liturgy.[http://www.sanctamissa.org/en/tutorial/ordo-missae-1.html Prayers at the Foot of the Altar] Joyce preferred to indicate spoken dialogue with a dash, in the Continental manner, rather than with inverted commas. The latter were used, against the author's wishes, in ''[[w:Dubliners|Dubliners]]'' and the first two editions of ''[[w:A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man|A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man]]''.Hans Walter Gabler, ''A Note on the Text'', in James Joyce, ''Dubliners'', Vintage International (1993), page 233. '''Chrysostomos'''{{spaces|5}}(''Greek'') ''Χρυσόστομος'' is Greek for ''golden-mouthed'', a common epithet meaning ''[[wikt:eloquent|eloquent]]'', though here it refers literally to Mulligan's [[w:Gold teeth|gold-pointed teeth]].Gifford (1988) 14.
Thornton (1968) 12. The epithet was applied to [[w:John Chrysostom|St John Chrysostomos]], one of the fathers of the Greek church, whose name recalls that of [[w:Oliver St. John Gogarty|Oliver ''St John'' Gogarty]], Joyce's principal model for Buck Mulligan. On 16 June, the feast of the [[wikt:confessor|confessor]] [[w:St. John Francis Regis|St John Francis Regis]], the fourth lesson of the [[w:Nocturns|Second Nocturn]] would have been taken from one of John Chrysostom's sermons.[http://www.archive.org/stream/romanbreviaryref03cath#page/457/mode/1up John, Marquess of Bute (translator), ''The Roman Breviary'' (1908) 457.] In Ireland [[w:Pope Gregory I|Pope Gregory the Great]] was known as ''Grigoir Belóir'' (''Gregory of the Golden Mouth'').[http://www.ucc.ie/celt/published/T100005A/index.html ''Annals of the Four Masters'' M590.4] and [http://www.ucc.ie/celt/published/G100005A/index.html ''Annála Ríoghachta Éireann'' M590.4.] There was also, reputedly, an Irish saint of the 6th-century known as ''Greoihir Belóir'' (''Gregory of the Golden Mouth''). He lived in a cave in the [[w:Aran Islands|Aran Islands]]. A local myth recounts that he bit off his lower lip while fretting over his sins, and a golden lip grew in its place.[http://www.archive.org/stream/irishlocallegend00ohan#page/n44/mode/1up John O'Hanlon, ''Irish Local Legends'' 27-29.] Gregory's Sound, between Inishmore and Inishmaan, is named after him. [[w:John Millington Synge|John Millington Synge]] mentions the Bay of Gregory of the Golden Mouth in his one-act play ''[[w:Riders to the Sea|Riders to the Sea]]''.[http://www.one-act-plays.com/dramas/riders_to_the_sea.html ''Riders to the Sea''.] In his early satire ''Gas from a Burner'' (1912), Joyce refers to [[w:Augusta, Lady Gregory|Lady Gregory]] as ''Gregory of the Golden Mouth''.[http://groups.google.com/group/alt.books.james-joyce/msg/9293e8a84ff978c9 ''Gas from a Burner'' 42.] '''Two strong shrill whistles''' The two whistles represent the [[w:Sacring-Bell|sacring bell]], which is rung during the elevation of the consecrated Host during Mass. The origin of these helpful whistles is still a mystery. There are two obvious sources: (1) the mailboat, which is just about to leave Kingtown Harbour, about 1200 metres away (see [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Telemachus/005|005.17]]) (2) a train arriving at Sandycove Railway Station, about 900 metres away. In the live reading of ''Ulysses'', broadcast in 1982 on ''[[w:Raidió Teilifís Éireann|Raidió Éireann]]'' to commemorate Joyce's centenary, the two whistles were represented by two blasts of a ship's whistle. But the resulting sound is hardly ''shrill'', sounding more like a tuba than a piccolo. I prefer the train whistle, which is normally of much higher pitch than a ship's whistle. In the final episode of ''Ulysses'', Molly hears two train whistles (see [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Penelope/706|706.05]] and [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Penelope/713|713.11]]). It is possible that Joyce intended a connection between these two events, linking the novel's most [[w:Mephistopheles|Mephistophelean]] character at the beginning of the book with the [[w:Eternal feminine|Ever-Womanly]] Molly at the end. Molly's bedroom at 7 Eccles Street is only about 600 metres from [[w:Drumcondra railway station|Drumcondra Railway Station]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/001|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/004|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

revision.comment: fixed my own terrible treatment of jejune
revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=7]]
==Annotations== 004.13 {{spaces|5}} '''Two dactyls''' Buck Mulligan's real name, Malachi Mulligan, contains two groupings of three syllables. A dactyl is a metrical foot used in poetry which contains a stress on the first syllable, as ''Mal''*ach*i ''Mull''*i*gan. [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dactyl_(poetry)] ''Dactyl (poetry'' Wikipedia article. 004.17 '''Jejune''' {{spaces|5}} Mulligan's modifier for "jesuit" reflects the tone of the chapter towards the Catholic faith, tradition, and liturgy.
{{spaces|5}} (1) without interest or significance; dull; insipid: a jejune novel.
{{spaces|5}} (2) juvenile; immature; childish: jejune behavior.
{{spaces|5}} (3) lacking knowledge or experience; uninformed: jejune attempts to design a house. [http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/jejune] ''Jejune'' Dictionary.com article
==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 26%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/003|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/005|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=8]]
==Annotations== 005.12 '''Algy calls it . . . mother?''' {{spaces|5}} Algernon "Algy" Charles Swinburne, a Victorian poet, wrote these words in the poem "A Triumph of Time." On line 257 and 258, he writes "I will go back to the great sweet mother,/Mother and lover of men, the sea." [http://www.victorianweb.org/authors/swinburne/triumph.html "A Triumph of Time" by A. C. Swinburne] ''The Poems of Algernon Charles Swinburne'', 6 volumes, London: Chatto & Windus, 1904. The imagery of the sea here is feminine and sexual, set in direct apposition to Buck's use of "snotgreen" and "scrotumtightening" as descriptors of the sea. 005.13 '''''Epi oinopa ponton'''''{{spaces|5}}(''[[w:Homeric Greek|Homeric Greek]]'') ''Upon the wine-coloured sea''.Gifford (1988) 15.
Thornton (1968) 12. The Homeric epithet ''ἐπὶ οἴνοπα πόντον'' occurs several times in the ''[[w:Odyssey|Odyssey]]'', the first occurrence being at 1:183.[http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0135%3Abook%3D1%3Acard%3D178 ''Odyssey'' 1:178-229.] The precise meaning of ''οἴνοπα'' (''wine-faced, wine-dark, wine-coloured'', or something else) has been endlessly debated by scholars. Nevertheless, this phrase remains perhaps the best-known quotation from ancient Greek literature, one which scholars of the language are sure to encounter in their first months of study. By putting this quote into Mulligan's mouth, Joyce is not doing Mulligan's scholarship any favours. Ironically, the Classical Greek which Mulligan would have learned at Oxford was not [[w:Pronunciation of Ancient Greek in teaching|pronounced]] according to the reconstructed pronunciation of Ancient Greek; the Classical Association, which promoted the introduction of a more authentic pronunciation, was only founded in 1903.[http://www.classicalassociation.org/ The Classical Association.] So Mulligan has almost as little experience of the Greeks ''in the original'' as Stephen. 005.15 '''''Thalatta! Thalatta!'''''{{spaces|5}}(''[[w:Attic Greek|Attic Greek]]'') ''The sea! The sea!''Gifford (1988) 15.
Thornton (1968) 13. ''[[w:Thalatta! Thalatta!|θάλαττα θάλαττα]]'' is a familiar quotation from the ''[[w:Anabasis (Xenophon)|Anabasis]]'' (''The Inland Expedition'') of [[w:Xenophon|Xenophon]].[http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0201%3Abook%3D4%3Achapter%3D7%3Asection%3D24 Xenophon, ''Anabasis'' 4:7:24.] The joyful cry of the Ten Thousand Greek mercenaries upon finally reaching the Black Sea is one of the best-known quotations from ancient Greek literature. Joyce is once again undermining Mulligan's scholarship by having him quote such a familiar phrase. 005.24 '''hyperborean''' {{spaces|5}} A word comprised of "hyper-," a Greek term meaning beyond or above, and "borean," a term referring to the north wind. [http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/hyperborean] Dictionary.com definition of "Hyperborean." The Hyperboreans were said to live in a land beyond where the north wind dwelt in Thrace. This mythical land was perfect, and the sun shone all the time, perhaps suggesting a place within the arctic circle. In Joyce, "Hyperborean" is used to refer to a character's Celtic origin, having come from Asia and settled in Ireland, beyond the north wind.[w:Hyperborea|Hyperborea] ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 26%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/004|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/006|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=9]]
==Annotations== 006.12 '''bowsy''' {{spaces|5}} Gurrier, lout; an uncouth or aggressive young man. [http://homepage.tinet.ie/~nobyrne/b.htm] 006.23 '''g. p. i.''' {{spaces|5}} General Paresis of the Insane is a kind of paralytic dementia which affects the brain and nervous system, resulting in seizures and other muscular reflex abnormalities. At the time, doctors did not know that GPI was caused by syphilitic infection.[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_paresis_of_the_insane General Paresis of the Insane] Here, Buck Mulligan refers to GPI as Genera Paralysis of the Insane, when it is not "Paralysis," but "Paresis." Despite his medical background (014.18, 19), he is still ignorant of this fact. 006.31 '''dogsbody''' {{spaces|5}} someone who does drudge work. [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dogsbody} 006.36 '''Caliban . . . mirror''' {{spaces|5}} [[Wikipedia:Caliban|Caliban]] is, most famously, a monstrous character in William Shakespeare's play ''The Tempest.'' However, the reference to the mirror is from another work: Oscar Wilde's preface to ''The Picture of Dorian Gray''. In it, Wilde says that "The nineteenth century dislike of Realism is that of Caliban seeing his own face in the glass. The nineteenth century dislike of Romanticism is that of Caliban not seeing his own face in the glass." [http://www.gutenberg.org/ebooks/26740 ''The Picture of Dorian Gray'' by Oscar Wilde. London: Simpkin, Marshall, Hamilton, Kent, & co. (1916)] As Mulligan pulls the mirror away from Daedalus' face, he says "If only Wilde could see you now," as if to suggest that Daedalus has somehow opposed Wilde's aphorism. ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 26%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid #bfb; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/005|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/007|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

revision.comment: added a reference to Matthew Arnold
revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=10]]
==Annotations== 007.30 '''Matthew Arnold''' {{spaces|5}} [[w:Matthew_Arnold|Matthew_Arnold]] was a poet who lived from 1822 to 1888 and wrote mostly on contemporary social issues. [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matthew_Arnold Wikipedia's page on Matthew Arnold] The significance of a deaf gardener masked with Arnold's face is that the social critic is totally focused on what he can see--"watching narrowly the dancing motes of grasshalms"--rather than anything he can perceive with other senses. 007.32 '''omphalos'''{{spaces|5}}(''Homeric Greek'') ''navel'', ''centre''.Gifford (1988) 17.
Thornton (1968) 15. In the ''[[w:Odyssey|Odyssey]]'', the island of [[w:Ogygia|Ogygia]], on which Odysseus is being detained by the nymph Calypso at the beginning of the epic, is described thus: {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''Odyssey 1:48-50[http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0135%3Abook%3D1%3Acard%3D44 ''Odyssey'' 1:48-50.]''''' |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ''ἀλλά μοι ἀμφ᾽ Ὀδυσῆι δαΐφρονι δαίεται ἦτορ,'' ''δυσμόρῳ, ὃς δὴ δηθὰ φίλων ἄπο πήματα πάσχει'' ''νήσῳ ἐν ἀμφιρύτῃ, ὅθι τ᾽ '''ὀμφαλός''' ἐστι θαλάσσης.'' | ''But my heart is torn for wise Odysseus,'' ''Hapless man, who far from his friends has long been suffering woes'' ''In a sea-girt isle, where is the '''navel''' of the sea'' |} Several locations have been identified with Ogygia, including Ireland. See also [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Telemachus/017|017.31]], [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Proteus/038|038.14]] and [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Oxen_of_the_Sun/383|383.32]]. The term ''[[wikt:omphalos|omphalos]]'' has a number of meanings which resonate throughout ''Ulysses'':{{cite book |title=James Joyce's Ulysses: A Study |last=Gilbert |first=Stuart |year=1930}} :'''[[wikt:navel|Navel]]'''{{spaces|5}}symbolical of birth and the interconnectedness of all life; the seat of the soul and the point at which mystics stare while meditating. Stephen may be suggesting that contemporary Irish nationalism was little more than self-centred [[wikt:navel-gazing|navel-gazing]]. See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Proteus/038|038.11 ff.]] :'''Centre of the world'''{{spaces|5}}The [[w:Pythia|Oracle of Delphi]] was believed to be located at the centre of the world, which was represented by a stone known as the ''[[w:Omphalos|omphalos]]''. In some editions of ''Ulysses'', the word ''omphalos'' is italicized. See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Telemachus/017|017.31]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 26%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/006|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/008|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

revision.comment: added Sir Peter Teazle and Lalouette's
revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=11]]
==Annotations== 008.30 '''Sir Peter Teazle''' {{spaces|5}} [[w:Sir_Peter_Teazle|Sir_Peter_Teazle]] was a British thoroughbred racehorse. His name is used as a then-familiar example of why Daedalus' mother had lost touch with reality. 008.32 '''hired mute from Lalouette's''' {{spaces|5}} In the [[w:Victorian_era|Victorian_era]], mourners were commonly hired for funerals to add to the atmosphere. These people were dressed in dull colors and stood near the entrance to the home or church, looking somber. Lalouette's, Gifford and Seidman note, was a Dublin mortuary whose rental services included mutes. [http://joyceproject.com/notes/010070mutes.htm The Joyce Project] Mulligan's reference would have been obvious to Daedalus, because mutes had been in common use since Elizabethan England, and Lalouette's was famous in the region. ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 26%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid #bfb; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/007|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/009|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

revision.comment: added Sassenach and the Yeats poem
revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=12]]
==Annotations== 009.13 '''Sassenach''' {{spaces|5}} "Sassenach" is a Gàidhlig loanword, denoting "Saxon." It bears a disparaging meaning, and is often used in jest. [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saxons Wikipedia's page on Saxon] 009.20-22 '''''And no more . . . brazen cars''''' {{spaces|5}} These words are from a poem by William Butler Yeats titled ''Who Goes with Fergus.'' [http://www.poemhunter.com/poem/who-goes-with-fergus/ ''Who Goes with Fergus'' by William Butler Yeats] Joyce repeatedly quotes poems by Yeats, perhaps to reinforce his statement about the cracked mirror as "a symbol of Irish art" on page 007.02. http://www.spectacle.org/398/thoughts.html Five Ideas about Joyce] ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 26%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid #bfb; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/008|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/010|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

revision.comment: added a reference to the two offset poems
revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=13]]
==Annotations== 010.05 '''I am the boy . . . invisibility''' {{spaces|5}} From a popular musical of the day called ''Turko the Terrible.'' In it, King Turko sings about how he will use his newfound gift of invisibility, given him by a rose. [http://joyceproject.com/notes/010078invisibility.htm The Joyce Project] Daedalus' mother hid that she attended bawdy shows, and this poem is used to illustrate that fact. 010.09 '''And no more . . . brood''' {{spaces|5}} From the same Yeats poem as 009.20. 010.21 '''''Liliata rutilantium te confessorum turma circumdet : iubilantium te virginum chorus excipiat'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''May the lilied throng of radiant Confessors encompass thee; may the choir of rejoicing Virgins welcome thee.'' These words are taken from the ''Ordo Commendationis Animae'' (''Rite for the Commending of a Departing Soul''),[http://www.preces-latinae.org/thesaurus/Varia/CommendatioAnimae.html ''Ordo Commendationis Animae''.] one of the Prayers for the Dying that form part of the [[w:Last Rites|Last Rites]] given to Catholics at the point of death. This prayer can be found in the ''[[w:Roman Ritual|Roman Ritual]]'' (''Rituale Romanum''), the official book of the [[w:Roman Rite|Roman Rite]] containing all the services not found in the ''[[w:Missale Romanum|Missal]]'' or ''[[w:Brevarium Romanum|Breviary]]''. It comprises the seventh chapter of the title ''Anointing of the Sick''.[http://www.archive.org/stream/ritualeromanumpa00cath#page/156/mode/1up ''Rituale Romanum''] Stephen would have heard these words when the Last Rites were being given to his dying mother. ''Liliata'', "lilied", means "as white as lilies" or "as bright as lilies". ''[[wikt:confessor|Confessors]]'' are saints who suffered for their faith but were not martyred for it. ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/009|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/011|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=14]]
==Annotations== 011.12-17 '''''O, won't we have . . . coronation day?''''' {{spaces|5}} One form of an English song to commemorate the coronation of King Edward VII. Its words are repeated several times through the book. It is one of many ditties which Mulligan disrespectfully sings to refer to his surroundings or situation. In this case, he may be using "coronation day" as a rough slang for "payday," because the amount could be reckoned in crowns. [http://www.cas.umt.edu/english/joyce/notes/010029coronation.htm] 011.28 '''barbacans''' {{spaces|5}} or barbican: an outwork of a fortified place, as a castle; a defensive outpost of any sort. [http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/barbican Dictionary.com Barbican] ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/010|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/012|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=15]]
==Annotations== 012.26 '''''In nomine Patris et Filii et Spiritus Sancti'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''In the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit.'' A common [[w:Trinitarian formula|Trinitarian formula]] used in numerous prayers and rites of the Catholic Church and when making the [[w:Sign of the Cross|Sign of the Cross]]. In the context of the parody of the Catholic Mass, begun by Mulligan on the [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Telemachus/003|opening page]] of the novel, the priest would first intone these words while making the Sign of the Cross before the antiphon ''Intoibo ad altare Dei'', and later at the beginning of the [[w:Introit|Introit]]. By placing them here in the midst of the [[w:Eucharist|Eucharist]], Mulligan is again perverting the order of the liturgy.{{cite book |last1 = Gifford |first1 = Don |last2 = Seidman |first2 = Robert J. |title = Ulysses Annotated |publisher = University of California Press |year = 1988 |page = 20}}
{{cite book |last = Thornton |first = Weldon |title = Allusions in Ulysses |publisher = The University of North Carolina Press |year = 1968 |page = 18}} 012.37 '''begob''' {{spaces|5}} A mild Irish oath meaning "by God." [http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/begob Wiktionary: Begob] Joyce adds "begob" to authenticate the wheedling old woman whom Mulligan is impersonating. ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/011|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/013|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=16]]
==Annotations== 013.9 '''Mabinogion''' {{spaces|5}} [[w:Mabinogion|The Mabinogion]] is a title given to eleven collected medieval Welsh folk tales. These tales were collected and translated into English in the mid 19th century by Lady Charlotte Guest. They span a large range of topics and use pre-Christian Celtic mythology, folktalke motifs, and medieval historical traditions. [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mabinogion Wikipedia article: Mabinogion] 013.9 '''Upanishads''' {{spaces|5}} [[w:Upanishads|The Upanishads]] are a collection of texts from the stories that form the basis for the Hindu religion. Their importance in India is still significant, for with the [[w:Bhagavad_Gita|Bhagavad Gita]] and [[w:Brahmasutra|Brahmasutra]] the oldest of these nearly 200 texts form the basis of many older Hindu philosophies.[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Upanishads Wikipedia article: Upanishads] Joyce referenced the Mabinogion and the Upanishads to give mother Grogan's tea a certain air of antiquity, and to give Mulligan a certain air of pompous self-importance. None of the men in the tower had any reason to suspect that Grogan's tea was in any ancient texts. 013.20 '''finical''' {{spaces|5}} finicky,[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/finical Dictionary.com "finical"] in other words, excessively particular or fastidious; difficult to please; fussy.[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/finicky Dictionary.com "finicky"] ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 26%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid #bfb; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/012|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/014|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=17]]
==Annotations== 014.05 '''dugs''' {{spaces|5}} the mamma or the nipple of a female mammal.[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/dugs Dictionary.com "dugs"] 014.08 '''cuckquean''' {{spaces|5}} a woman who has an unfaithful husband. [http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/cuckquean Wiktionary "cuckquean"] As a woman whose husband is dead is a widow, so a woman whose husband is a cuckold is a cuckquean. 014.18 '''Are you a medical student, sir?''' {{spaces|5}} The milkwoman asks Mulligan if he is a medical student. He answers in the affirmative, claiming medical knowledge. Joyce has undermined this knowledge as recently as 006.24, when Mulligan incorrectly identifies the definition of GPI. ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 26%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid #bfb; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/013|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/015|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

revision.comment:
Created page with "[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=18]]
==Annotations== ==References== {| style="width: 26%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-co..."
revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=18]]
==Annotations== ==References== {| style="width: 26%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid #bfb; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/014|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/016|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=19]]
==Annotations== '''Agenbite of inwit'''{{spaces|5}}(''Middle English'') ''Remorse of conscience''.Gifford (1988) 22.
Thornton (1968) 22-22. Stephen has modernized the [[w:Middle English|Middle English]] spelling ''[[w:Ayenbite of Inwyt|Ayenbite of Inwyt]]''. This is the title of a translation of a French moral treatise ''Le Somme de Vices et de Virtues'' (''The Book of Vices and Vertues''), written in 1279 by the Dominican monk Frère Lorens (Laurentius Gallus). Lorens was confessor to [[w:Philip III of France|Philip III of France]] and it was for the king that he wrote the treatise. It is a layman's manual of sins and virtues, similar in content and style to ''[[w:The Parson's Tale|The Parson's Tale]]'' in [[w:Geoffrey Chaucer|Geoffrey Chaucer's]] ''[[w:The Canterbury Tales|Canterbury Tales]]''. The English translation was made in 1340 by [[w:Dan Michel of Northgate|Dan Michel of Northgate]], and is highly valued today by scholars of Middle English, being one of the few surviving works in the Kentish dialect.[http://www.archive.org/stream/danmichelsayenb00michgoog#page/n4/mode/2up Dan Michel of Northgate, ''Ayenbite of Inwyt''.] See also [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Telemachus/017|017.03]], [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Calypso/058|058.11]], [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Calypso/066|066.15]], [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Lestrygonians/160|160.33]], [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Lestrygonians/175|175.12, 14]], [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Scylla_and_Charybdis/181|181.33]], [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Scylla_and_Charybdis/189|189.26]], [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Scylla_and_Charybdis/198|198.11-12]], [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Wandering_Rocks/233|233.32, 36]], [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Sirens/268|268.21]], [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Nausicaa/364|364.26]], [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Oxen_of_the_Sun/373|373.34]], [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Oxen_of_the_Sun/394|394.04]], [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Circe/440|440.04-05]], [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Circe/467|467.23]], [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Circe/469|469.01-02]], [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Ithaca/659|659.23-24]] and [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Ithaca/670|670.30]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 26%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/015|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/017|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

revision.comment: added mercurial and a link to point to the previous use of omphalos
revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=20]]
==Annotations== 017.06 '''mercurial''' {{spaces|5}} Buck uses "mercurial" here to set himself against the jesuit he described as jejune on [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce%27s_Ulysses/Telemachus/004|004.17]].
{{spaces|5}} 1. changeable; volatile; fickle; flighty; erratic: a mercurial nature.
{{spaces|5}} 2. animated; lively; sprightly; quick-witted.
{{spaces|5}} 3. pertaining to, containing, or caused by the metal mercury.
{{spaces|5}} 4. (initial capital letter) of or pertaining to the god Mercury.
{{spaces|5}} 5. (initial capital letter) of or pertaining to the planet Mercury. [http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/mercurial Dictionary.com definition "mercurial"]
017.33 '''omphalos''' {{spaces|5}} Used on [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce%27s_Ulysses/Telemachus/007|007.32]] to indicate the rock at the center or navel of the world. ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 26%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid #bfb; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/016|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/018|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

revision.comment: fixed an error in my link
revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=21]]
==Annotations== 018.05 '''proves by algebra''' {{spaces|5}} This is explained more fully on [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce%27s_Ulysses/Nestor/028|028.18]], within context. 018.16 '''Elsinore''' {{spaces|5}} The castle in Shakespeare's ''Hamlet''. The italicized line is a quote from act 1 scene 4, line 77, in which Horatio describes the way the cliff hangs over its base.[http://www.enotes.com/hamlet-text/act-i-scene-iv enotes.com Text of Shakespeare's ''Hamlet''] 018.33 '''The Ballad of Joking Jesus''' {{spaces|5}} The song inscribed in the text is a modified form of the poem [[w:The_Song_of_the_Cheerful_(but_slightly_Sarcastic)_Jesus|The Song of the Cheerful (but slightly Sarcastic) Jesus]] by [[w:Oliver_St._John_Gogarty|Oliver St. John Gogarty]]. [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Song_of_the_Cheerful_(but_slightly_Sarcastic)_Jesus Wikipedia entry regarding The Song of the Cheerful (but slightly Sarcastic) Jesus] Joyce uses it as a continued satirical comment on the Catholic church by having Mulligan sing, who has taken on the voice of the maudlin priest in this mass. Dedalus refers to it as a prayer on [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce%27s_Ulysses/Telemachus/019|019.23]], saying that he has heard the joke three times daily, after meals. ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 26%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid #bfb; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/017|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/019|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

revision.comment:
Created page with "[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=22]]
==Annotations== ==References== {| style="width: 26%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-co..."
revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=22]]
==Annotations== ==References== {| style="width: 26%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid #bfb; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/018|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/020|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

revision.comment: added page and line numbers to the existing annotation
revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=23]]
==Annotations== 020.32 '''''et unam sanctam catholicam et apostolicam ecclesiam'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''and [in] one holy catholic and apostolic church.'' These words are taken from the [[w:Nicene Creed|Nicene Creed]], part of the [[w:Ordinary|Ordinary]] of the [[w:Tridentine Mass|Tridentine Mass]], which is parodied throughout this episode of the novel. The four adjectives, known as the [[w:Four Marks of the Church|Four Marks of the Church]], assert the uniqueness of the Catholic Church, its sanctity, its universality and its origins in the teachings that Christ imparted to his [[w:Apostles|Apostles]].{{cite book |last1 = Gifford |first1 = Don |last2 = Seidman |first2 = Robert J. |title = Ulysses Annotated |publisher = University of California Press |year = 1988 |page = 25}}
{{cite book |last = Thornton |first = Weldon |title = Allusions in Ulysses |publisher = The University of North Carolina Press |year = 1968 |page = 24}} ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: White; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/019|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/021|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=25]]
==Annotations== '''''Uebermensch'' ... the supermen'''{{spaces|5}}(''German'') literally ''Superman''.Gifford (1988) 27.
Thornton (1968) 26. The ''[[w:Übermensch|Übermensch]]'' is a philosophical concept introduced by Thomas Carlyle in 1840 in his book ''On Heroes, Hero-Worship and the Heroic in History''.[[w:Great_Man_theory|Wikipedia entry on Great Man Theory]] The book proposed that "The history of the world is but the biography of great men,"{{cite book |last=Hirsch |first=E.D. |title=The New Dictionary of Cultural Literacy (Third Edition) |publisher=Houghton Mifflin Company |city=Boston |year=2002}} and that each era of human civilization was defined by the abilities and religion of its Übermensch. Used this way, Joyce would be advocating that his heros are the defining force behind their society.
However, Herbert Spencer believed the causal relationship worked the opposite way. Instead, he argued that society defined its own Übermensch. {{cite book |last=Spencer |first=Herbert |title=The Study of Sociology |publisher=Appleton |year=1896 |page=34}} It is also possible that Joyce believes that his unassuming heroes are Übermenschen in that they are the obvious result of the society in which they live.
However, Joyce refers quite clearly to another work at 022.36. Mulligan says the title of a different work: ''Thus Spake Zarathustra.'' This references the Übermensch concept as discussed by [[w:Friedrich Nietzsche|Friedrich Nietzsche]] in 1883 in his book ''[[w:Thus Spake Zarathustra|Also Sprach Zarathustra]]'' (''Thus Spake Zarathustra''). Nietzsche used the term to describe a human being who has successfully transcended or surpassed human nature, one who has freed himself from Christian morality and spiritualism, one who has evolved to a higher state. See also [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Proteus/050|050.14]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 26%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/021|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/023|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=26]]
==Annotations== '''''Liliata rutilantium ... virginum'''''{{spaces|5}}See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Telemachus/010|010.21-22]]. Stephen's emended version, laid out as a [[w:tercet|tercet]], anticipates the tercet of ''Heighos'' at the end of ''[[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Calypso/067|Calypso]]''. Presumably it is 8:45 am as Stephen sets off for Dalkey. For Bloom, the bells of St George's Church are tolling for Paddy Dignam; for Stephen, the bells (real or imaginary) are ringing for his mother.{{cite book |last1 = Gunn |first1 = Ian |last2 = Hart |first2 = Clive |title = James Joyce's Dublin |publisher = Thames & Hudson |year = 2004 |page = 27 |isbn = 0-500-51159-4}} It is doubtful whether Stephen can actually hear any chimes. The closest church to him in 1904 was probably St Patrick's Church in Bullock Harbour, about 600 metres away, but it had no clock tower. St Joseph's Church on Summerhill Road, about 750 metres away, also lacked a clock tower. The closest clock tower was probably that on the Town Hall in Kingstown (now Dún Laoghaire), about 1.5 kilometres away. See also [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Ithaca/656|Ithaca 656.20 ff.]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Telemachus/021|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Nestor/024|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

Collegiate Shag has a few basic variations. The most popular is the 6-count Double Shag which uses a 'slow, slow, quick, quick' rhythm.
BASIC PATTERN: from the lead's point-of-view. (Follows, just mirror the Lead) :Beat 1: STEP onto left foot. :Beat 2: HOP on left. :Beat 3: STEP onto right foot :Beat 4: HOP on right. :Beat 5: STEP onto left foot. :Beat 6: STEP onto right foot.
Slow1&2, Slow3&4, Quick5, Quick6. The movements for 5&6 can be a shuffle-step, a run-in-place, or step-in-place. A familiar feeling is a jumping rope feeling. Be sure to do a full transfer of weight with the planted foot has all the weight.
POSITION: There is Solo, Open, Closed. *Solo is when you break apart have have no physical contact with partner. You rely on visual cues and maintain the beats. *Open is when you have a one or two handed hold, but are apart from each other. *Closed is when Lead's left hand holds the Follow's right hand. Lead's right hand on the Follow's left shoulderblade. Body position is offset with Lead's right foot in-between the flows feet. Traditionally the hand-hold is held straight up in the air, but you can also hold the hands at the shoulder level.
KICK PATTERNS: from the lead's point-of-view. (Follows, just mirror the Lead) One can kick down, to the side, in front, to the back, or tap the ground. :Beat 1: STEP onto left foot. :Beat 2: HOP on left while kicking the right foot. :Beat 3: STEP onto right foot :Beat 4: HOP on right while kicking the left foot. :Beat 5: STEP onto left foot. :Beat 6: STEP onto right foot.
TURNS: The Follows can be turned with an outside, inside, a free, texas tommy, or pass-by turns patterns. Traditionally, the Follow turns on the Quick-Quick (2counts), but they can also spin during the Slow-Slow (4counts).
{{BookCat}}

revision.comment: added annotations dealing with Asculum and Pyrrhus
revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=27]]
==Annotations== 024.12 '''Asculum''' {{spaces|5}} The site of abattle fought in the Pyrrhic war in 279 B.C., for which Joyce has his facts substantially correct.[[w:Battle_of_Asculum_(279_BC)|Wikipedia entry Battle of Asculum (279 BC)]] 024.18 '''Pyrrhus''' {{spaces|5}} The Macedonian general in the Pyrrhic wars. His "end" was caused by an old Aregead woman who dropped a roofing tile on him from above, allowing an Argive soldier to behead him.[[w:Pyrrhus_of_Epirus|Wikipedia entry Pyrrhus of Epirus]] This fate is referred to in [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce%27s_Ulysses/Nestor/025|025.21]] as "fallen by a beldam's (old woman's) hand." ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 26%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid #bfb; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=31]]
==Annotations== 028.18 '''proves by algebra''' {{spaces|5}} This is previously mentioned on [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce%27s_Ulysses/Telemachus/018|018.05]], when Mulligan uses it as an impressive facet of Dedalus' abilities. 028.32 '''''Amor matris'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''The love of a mother.'' ''A mother's love''. '''subjective and objective genitive'''{{spaces|5}}In grammar, the [[w:Genitive_case|genitive]] or possessive case has several different forms. The Latin phrase ''Amor matris'' is ambiguous to Stephen because it means two different things depending on whether ''matris'' is subjective genitive or objective genitive: :'''subjective genitive:''' ''A mother's love [for her child]'' :'''objective genitive:''' ''[A child's] love for his mother'' Stephen is thinking of himself and his own mother as much as he is thinking of Sargent and Sargent's mother.{{cite book |last1 = Gifford |first1 = Don |last2 = Seidman |first2 = Robert J. |title = Ulysses Annotated |publisher = University of California Press |year = 1988 |page = 34}} ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=35]]
==Annotations== '''lord Hastings' Repulse'''{{spaces|5}}[[w:Henry Weysford Charles Plantagenet, 4th Marquess of Hastings|Henry Weysford Charles Plantagenet]] (1842-1868), was a British peer.Gifford (1988) 37.
Thornton (1968) 37. In the Irish peerage he held the titles Earl of Moira and Baron Rawdon of Moira, both of which became extinct upon his death. His racehorse Repulse won the [[w:1000 Guineas Stakes|1000 Guineas Stakes]] at Newmarket in 1866 over a distance of 1 mile (1609 metres).[http://www.pedigreequery.com/repulse Repulse Horse Pedigree.] The winning jockey was Tom Cannon, Sr, a greatgrandfather of [[w:Lester Piggott|Lester Piggott]].[http://www.horseracinghistory.co.uk/hrho/action/viewDocument?id=1315 Tom Cannon, Sr.] The horse was trained by John Day, Jr. The 1000 Guineas is run by three-year old thoroughbred fillies. '''the duke of Westminster's Shotover'''{{spaces|5}}[[w:Hugh Grosvenor, 1st Duke of Westminster|Hugh Grosvenor]] (1825-1899) was a successful racehorse onwer and [[w:Master of the Horse|Master of the Horse]] from 1880-1885. His horse [[w:Shotover (horse)|Shotover]] won the [[w:Epsom Derby|Epsom Derby]] in 1882 over a distance of 1½ miles (2414 metres).[http://www.pedigreequery.com/shotover Shotover Horse Pedigree.] The winning jockey was Tom Cannon, who had ridden Repulse to victory in the 1000 Guineas sixteen years earlier.[http://www.horseracinghistory.co.uk/hrho/action/viewDocument?id=1315 Tom Cannon, Sr.] The horse was trained by [[w:John Porter (horseman|John Porter]]. Shotover also won the [[w:2000 Guineas Stakes|2000 Guineas Stakes]] in 1882 with the same jockey. The Epsom Derby and the 2000 Guineas are run by three-year old thoroughbreds. '''the duke of Beaufort's Ceylon, ''prix de Paris'', 1866'''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') The [[w:Grand Prix de Paris|Grand Prix de Paris]] is a French flat horse race for three-year old thoroughbreds.Gifford (1988) 37.
Thornton (1968) 37. Inaugurated in 1863, it is run every July at [[w:Longchamp Racecourse|Longchamp Racecourse]] in Paris. In 1866 it was indeed won by [[w:Henry Somerset, 8th Duke of Beaufort|Henry Somerset, 8th Duke of Beaufort's]] Ceylon over a distance of 3000 metres.[http://www.pedigreequery.com/ceylon Ceylon Horse Pedigree.] The winning jockey was once again Tom Cannon,[http://www.horseracinghistory.co.uk/hrho/action/viewDocument?id=1315 Tom Cannon.] and the trainer John Day. Beaufort (1824-1899) was the [[w:Master of the Horse|Master of the Horse]] from 1858-1859 and from 1866-1868. '''Elfin riders sat them'''{{spaces|5}}Presumably Repulse, Shotover and Ceylon are carrying the same rider: the jockey Tom Cannon, Sr, who rode them to victory in their Classic triumphs. Is Mr Deasy an admirer of Cannon? Jockeys are usually light and of diminutive build — [[wikt:elfin|elfin]]. The transitive use of the verb ''to sit'', meaning ''to sit upon'' or ''to ride'' is quite rare; it is most commonly used, as here, with reference to the riding of a horse.[http://www.archive.org/stream/dictionaryenglis02john#page/646/mode/1up Samuel Johnson, ''A Dictionary of the English Language'', Volume 2, ''s. v.'' '''Sit'''.] ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 26%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Nestor/031|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Nestor/033|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}
