== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Philovitist!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks. --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Italy.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 22:26, 23 November 2011 (UTC)

{{DISPLAYTITLE:From Data to Insight}} =Introduction= {{Book Search|prefix=From Data to Insight}} “...what is the use of a book," thought Alice, "without pictures...?”
This book teaches the principles of transforming data into insights: # All data represent one of 3 dimensions: WHAT | WHEN | WHERE? # Every datagraphic visualizes a relationship among the dimensions. # There is an appropriate visualization for every relationship. # The visualization should be efficiently designed. # The design should reveal the insight. =Data= A common approach to the treatment of data is that they are at the bottom of a hierarchy: #Wisdom #Knowledge #Information #Data whose lower levels are more 'dense' and less 'useful' and whose higher levels are more 'reduced' and abstract. This book deals mainly with the lowest three levels: how to transform data - largely through visualization - into insightful knowledge about the how the world seems to work. ==Relationships== ==Numbers== ==Geometry== =The Dimensions of Data= =Phenomena= We begin with the idea of discrete objects that are enumerable (can be counted) to yield a single number but perhaps measured in many ways. In what follows these objects won't be divided into their components. As shown in the exhibit, the fundamental data distinction is between numbers and what could be called labels.[[Image:measurement.jpg|thumb|a simple measurement hierarchy]] The simplest kinds of numbers are the integers '''I''', which are used to count objects. As the number of objects becomes large (say > 100) the difference between their counts becomes relatively small so that these counts become nearly continuous. Truly continuous numbers—the real numbers '''R'''1—can assume all possible values. Labels (sometimes called nominal values or factors) are used to distinguish objects without measuring an amount or any specific numeric quality, although labels can be ordered ("do not like", "indifferent", "like"). Counts can play the roles of labels when the values are small (e.g. single-person v. 2-person v. >2-person families). [[w:Combinatorics|Combinatorics]] deals with how labeling can be used to collect the objects into various 'bins' whose counts will be discussed in data [[From Data to Insight#Description|description]] below. It is important to know what kind of measurements are being dealt with because there are descriptive and relational methods appropriate to each kind. Let's examine a few examples, in the present case from the field of environmental analysis. * The number of trees in a [[w:quadrat|quadrat]] is an integer ranging from 0 to less than infinity. * The weight of a soil sample is a real number greater than 0 (although a sample could have zero weight, the question arises as to whether it is a sample at all, and, if so, whether there are therefore infinite such samples). * The proportion of Nitrates in a water sample measured in parts per million is a real number resulting from the act of division. * The magnitude of an earthquake is a real number, but because such numbers come from [[w:Long Tail|long-tailed distributions]], logarithms are often used. * A land cover class ('forest', 'water', 'cropland', 'urban') is a label associated with no number, although each class could be assigned an arbitrary integer (say 2, 4, 1, 3). Sometimes integers are used to label measurements, but these numbers (sometimes called 'keys' in database terminology) are identifiers and cannot be described further; moreover, they should be the first column of the [[From Data to Insight#Description|data matrix]]. A particularly complicated kind of measurement results in various kinds of categories, which require often sophisticated analytical techniques. One example would be assigning a human patient to the class of patients suffering from [[w:West Nile Virus|West Nile Virus]], which can be considered an anatomical condition (brain inflammation), an infection by a specific Flavivirus, or a collection of symptoms (fever, etc.). Measurement problem - issues of reliability and confidentiality - are among the reasons why epidemiological data description is so challenging. It is useful to explore some of the unusual conditions that arise in the treatment of real numbers. * Zero arises when there's nothing to count (as in a treeless region or an image pixel receiving no photons), or as the length of an instant of time ("2011-11-24 13:02:36.032 EST", where only milliseconds are shown). * Negative numbers are needed in e.g. spatial data to show altitude below sea level or angle below the equator, in time data to show years before the present, or phenomena to show temperature below freezing. * If some standard value is known then a 'rate' is computed most simply by dividing a measurement by that standard, as in a proportion of the whole or a percentage increase. * Finally there often arise unusual cases, where a measurement is missing (NA = not available or not applicable) or infinite (a ratio resulting from the division by zero). [[Image:wiki_Numbers.png|thumb|the 'behavior' of various kinds of numbers]] Critical to describing data is understanding how they behave. The exhibit shows that the fundamental continuum is between discrete and continuous measurements; if one keeps track of where a given measurement is on this continuum the appropriate descriptive approach should be clearer. ===Description=== Although most of this book will discuss how to visualize relationships between different kinds of measurements, much of analysis is concerned with simple description. We begin with the basic data matrix, as in the table below ID NOMINAL REGULAR INTEGER RATIONAL ------------------------------------------- Sigma D 28 2 9.1 Gamma B 29 7 9.7 Delta B 30 6 7.6 Kappa C 31 8 7.5 Mu D 32 8 9.8 Beta A 33 3 4.2 Pi D 34 6 4.7 Epsilon D 35 4 4.8 Tau C 36 8 4.2 Lambda C 37 10 2.0 Alpha A 38 9 5.8 Rho A 39 1 4.2 which is a 12 x 5 matrix of measurements that illustrate the key distinctions discussed so far: *The ID variable is a unique label that identifies each row. *NOMINAL is a not necessarily unique label consisting of a single alphabetic character, although it could easily be a number, or longer name. *REGULAR is a variable that increments in unit steps, and so could be either an index (the second row could be the 29th 'case) or a time stamp (year 1928). *INTEGER is a non-unique whole number that might be counting something. *RATIONAL is a real number that is a true measurement, say of wind speed in knots (and note that 'knots per hour' is incorrect unless you mean acceleration!). The above table is a useful illustration of where to begin with data visualization. It might be the complete data matrix (although 12 rows isn't very much) that you want to present in a report, in which case this is a clear template to use. Or the matrix might just be a sample of the full dataset; and - provided this sampling is indicated - the format is also useful. Finally, the table might be presenting statistics for 12 variables. In each of these cases I have presented a simple and clearly organized template. It's obviously very important to understand the data and to be completely clear what the data matrix represents, particularly: the numbers of rows and columns, the role of each column, and what it represents. Once this is clear, you can turn to the problem of describing each of the columns or variables. Each kind of measurement allows of its own set of descriptive statistics. Descriptive statistics present basic facts about your data. They are of two types: nonparametric and parametric, and they are easy to understand. ==== Nonparametric statistics ==== The range is the simplest description of your data: what are the smallest and largest values attained? For the 3rd column of the data above it's easy to see that REGULAR ranges from 28 to 39, INTEGER from 1 to 10, and RATIONAL FROM 2.0 TO 9.8. For a larger dataset you can sort the numbers and choose the smallest and largest. These numbers will help determine the axes of any plots that are drawn. The next statistic to examine is the [[w:Mode (statistics)|mode]], the most common value in the list. In a bar chart (the most appropriate visualization) the mode will have the longest bar.
[[image:d2i_Bar_chart.png]]
The above exhibit is about the simplest visual description of the NOMINAL variable. Note that the vertical axis shows the values ordered by their frequencies, so you can easily see which values are the most and least common. ===Analysis=== ===Examples=== ===Other topics=== =Time= =Space= =Relationships= =Applications= {{Subjects|Applied mathematics}}

page.title: Philosophy of Religion/God's will and obedience

revision.text:
God's will and obedience!
There are three nouns and a conjunction here! To understand this whole sentence, if it is one, we shall understand each one of them first and then juxtapose them as proposed and see if they make any sense in that order.
First noun is ''God''.To understand this concept (Yes, it is just a concept of one's mind of something that doesn't fit in any mind!), one take a look at [[Philosophy_of_Religion/Does_God_exist?|Does God exist?]] or [[Philosophy_of_Religion/Creator/destroyer|Creator/destroyer]]
Now let us come to His ''will''. If one understood ''God'' from the above references, then one would know his ''will'' too! You will realize that God and His will are not two separate and different things, and nor God stands apart from you like an object, a vacuum cleaner or a hammer or something else! So god's will is a funny meaningless expression, something like Ocean's wave! How self-standing and how extraneous is wave of an Ocean? So is the will of God.
Now comes the problematic word ''obedience!'' Now who obeys whom, when there are no two entities? Neither god, nor you but just One, the God, just You! So obedience is a meaningless word in this context. When understanding matures, what remains is mere execution of harmonious actions without appropriation of the outcomes to one's own self. There neither should or will remain a sense of ownership in doing, nor an expectation of any particular outcome for one's effort, but will be accompanied by a gracious acceptance of whatever finally transpires. The calmness and the serenity that is never lost even in that commotion of intense effort is the best possible meaning for obedience. And if one wants to call that obedience, yes, that could be the best befitting definition to this last piece of the puzzle.
At the end we come to ''and''. This word is for dramatization, that falls out of the thinking that something exalted being stated in the sentence, while in reality whole thing never made any sense!
Now go back to the sentence and contemplate. You will know the meaning! {{BookCat}}

This lesson will focus on broadening your vocabulary, allowing you to say short sentences and understanding the structure of Hawaiian.
==Vocabulary== ===Nouns=== ka pua -flower
ke kula -school
ka 'ohana -family
ka lani -heaven/sky
ke kanaka -man
ke aloha -love
ka wahine -woman
ka honua -earth
ka makua -parent
ka wai -water
ke keiki -child
ka haumana -student
=== Adjectives === li'ili'i -little
nui -big
nani -pretty
pupuka -ugly
hau'oli -happy
kaumaha -sad
māluhiluhi -tired
ma'i -sick
===Verbs===
hele -go
'ai -eat
hele mai -come
moe -sleep
hana -work
holo -run
==Review==
As you have learned in lesson 1, "Aia" is placed at the beginning of a sentence to show the subject's location (when or where). ex) Aia ka pua ma ke kula. (location) The flower (is) at the school.
-Notice how there is no word for "to be" verbs in Hawaiian; it all depends on the position of a word in the sentence. ex) Ka pua li'ili'i (the little flower) is a part of a sentence, while Li'ili'i ka pua'a. (The flower is little) demonstrates a whole sentence. -Notice how "ka pua'a" went from the beginning to the end.
Next, let's look at, "Nani ke keiki". This means, the girl is beautiful, but literally translates to, "Beautiful the girl" because the adjective is in front. For future references, note that the adjective comes after the noun it describes.
===Ke vs. Ka===
In Hawaiian, there are two ways to express the definite article (the). Ka is used most of the time, before every word not starting with k, e, a, or o.
===Pronouns=== '''Wau or au''' translate as I ''''Oe''' means you (singular) ''''O ia''' means he, she or it.
==Noun Announcers== Noun announcers basically come before a noun in a sentence, announcing that it is coming. Every noun is preceded by a noun announcer, most of the time, it being "ka" or "ke". Along with ka and ke, other announcers include 'o, kēia (this), kēlā (that), ko'u (my), kou (your), and kona (his/her).
==Practice Phrases==
Translate into Hawaiian for practice: {| valign="top" !align="left"|'''ʻŌlelo Pelekane''' !width="30" align="top"| !align="left"|'''ʻŌlelo Hawaiʻi''' |- |The good flower | |Ka pua'a maika'i |-
|I go. | |Hele au. |-
|The pretty child runs. | |Holo ke keiki nani. |-
|The sick parent | |Ka makua ma'i |-
|The woman is tired. | |Mālohilohi ka wahine. |- {{BookCat}}

page.title: Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Lotus Eaters/069

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=72]]
==Annotations== '''''dolce far niente'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Italian'') ''pleasant idleness''.Gifford (1988) 85. The literal translation of this common Italian expression is ''[[wikt:dolce far niente|sweet doing nothing]]''. '''Azotes'''{{spaces|5}} ''[[wikt:azote|Azote]]'' is an archaic name for [[w:Nitrogen|nitrogen]], the commonest constituent of the Earth's atmosphere. The French chemist [[w:Antoine Lavoisier|Antoine Lavoisier]] called this gas ''azote'', from the Greek roots ἀ (a) and ζωή (zōē) meaning ''not-life'', because it could not support life. Most plants, however, require nitrogen, which is probably what Bloom is thinking of. He seems to believe that such plants are called ''azotes'', though I have not found any references to support such a belief.[http://archive.org/stream/popularcyclopae05carpgoog William Benjamin Carpenter, ''Popular Cyclopaedia of Natural Science'' (1844), "Animal Physiology", p. 25.] ''... most plants require the element nitrogen or azote as one of the materials of their growth....'' It is possible that he has confused ''azote'' with ''[[wikt:exotic|exotic]]'', a plant that is not native to the local ecosystem. Exotics are to be found in the hothouse in Dublin's Botanic Gardens, alluded to by Bloom immediately after ''azotes''. Richard Ellmann referred to such near misses as ''Bloomisms''.{{cite book |title=Ulysses on the Liffey |last=Ellmann |first=Richard |year=1984 |publisher=Faber and Faber Limited |location=London |isbn=0-571-13309-6 |page=36}} ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 26%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Lotus_Eaters/068|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Lotus_Eaters/070|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

==Annotations== '''''Voglio e non'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Italian'') See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Calypso/061|061.33]]. Bloom has repeated his earlier mistake. '''''Là ci darem la mano ... la'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Italian'') ''There we shall join hands''. See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Calypso/061|061.20]]. Bloom's ''La la lala la la'' matches the musical rhythm of the following line, whose words he has possibly forgotten: ''Là mi dirai di sì'' (''There you shall say "Yes" to me''). ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 26%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''

page.title: Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Lotus Eaters/077

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=80]]
==Annotations== '''S. J.'''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Societas Iesu'', the [[w:Society of Jesus|Society of Jesus]] or Jesuits. In Latin an initial ''I'' followed by a vowel is interchangeable with ''J''. '''D. D.'''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Divinitatis Doctor'', [[w:Doctor of Divinity|Doctor of Divinity]]. It signifies that a [[w:doctorate|doctorate]] in [[w:divinity|divinity]] has been conferred on Dr William J. Walsh. '''Ecce Home.'''{{spaces|5}}(''Erratum'') Ecce Homo. This has been corrected in every edition of ''Ulysses'' I have examined, but ''Ecce Home'' is a common mistake made by those not familiar with the Latin language. It is precisely the sort of mistake Bloom might make.{{cite book |last1 = Ellmann |first1 = Richard |title = Ulysses on the Liffey |publisher = Faber and Faber |year = 1984 |page = 36}} [[File:Munkácsy-Ecce homo.jpg|thumb|right|''Ecce Homo'']] '''Ecce Homo'''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Behold the man''.{{cite book |last1 = Gifford |first1 = Don |last2 = Seidman |first2 = Robert J. |title = Ulysses Annotated |publisher = University of California Press |year = 1988 |page = 92}}
{{cite book |last1 = Thornton|first1 = Weldon|title = Allusions in Ulysses |publisher = University of North Carolina Press |year = 1968 |pages = 82-83}} In the [[w:Gospel of John|Gospel of John]], these words are spoken by [[w:Pontius Pilate|Pontius Pilate]] when he presents Jesus to the people:''Then came Jesus forth, wearing the crown of thorns, and the purple robe. And Pilate saith unto them, Behold the man!''[http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Ioannes+19&version=VULGATE John 19:5] In 1899 a painting by the Hungarian artist [[w:Mihály Munkácsy|Mihály Munkácsy]] entitled ''Ecce Homo'' (1896) was exhibited in the [[w:Royal Hibernian Academy|Royal Hibernian Academy]] on [[w:Abbey Street|Lower Abbey Street]]. It depicted Christ wearing the crown of thorns and the purple robe. In September of the same year the seventeen-year-old Joyce wrote a short essay about the painting.{{cite book |last1 = Joyce |first1 = James |title = Occasional, Critical and Political Writing |editor = Kevin Barry |publisher = Oxford University Press |year = 2000 |pages = 17-22}} It is possible that Bloom is referring to this painting. '''''Corpus'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Body''. In the [[w:Tridentine Mass|Latin Mass]], each time the priest offers the [[w:Eucharist|consecrated bread]] to a communicant, he says ''Corpus Domini nostri Jesu Christi custodiat animam tuam in vitam æternam. Amen.'' (''May the Body of Our Lord Jesus Christ preserve your soul for eternal life. Amen'').[http://www.sanctamissa.org/en/resources/missale-romanum-pdf.html ''Missale Romanum'', ''Ritus Servandus'' X:6 (Page 73).] ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Lotus_Eaters/076|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Lotus_Eaters/078|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

page.title: Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Lotus Eaters/078

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=81]]
==Annotations== '''I. N. R. I.'''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Iesus Nazarenus Rex Iudaeorum'' (''Jesus the Nazarene, King of the Jews'').{{cite book |last1 = Gifford |first1 = Don |last2 = Seidman |first2 = Robert J. |title = Ulysses Annotated |publisher = University of California Press |year = 1988 |page = 94}}
{{cite book |last1 = Thornton|first1 = Weldon|title = Allusions in Ulysses |publisher = University of North Carolina Press |year = 1968 |page = 84}} According to [[w:Gospel of John|John 19:19]], this was the inscription Pilate wrote and placed on Christ's cross.[http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=John%2019&version=VULGATE John 19.] The original Greek form is '''ιησους ο ναζωραιος ο βασιλευς των ιουδαιων''' (''Iēsous ho Nazōraios ho Basileus tōn Ioudaiōn''). According to John 19:20, the inscription was written in Hebrew (which probably means [[w:Aramaic|Aramaic]]), Latin and Greek. The original Greek '''ο ναζωραιος''' has been translated ''[[w:Nazareth|of Nazareth]]'' and ''[[w:Nazarene (title)|the Nazarene]]''. ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Lotus_Eaters/077|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Lotus_Eaters/079|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

page.title: Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Lotus Eaters/079

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=82]]
==Annotations== '''''vibrato'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Italian'') ''vibrated''. In English ''[[w:Vibrato|vibrato]]'' is a technical term which describes the musical technique of quickly and repeatedly raising and lowering the pitch of a note by a small amount in order to impart an emotional expressiveness to the note. The practice is particularly associated with vocal music and [[w:String instrument|string technique]]. Some types of [[w:Pipe organ|organ]] can produce a similar effect by altering the pressure of the air passing through the pipes. Bloom is probably thinking of the [[w:Vox humana|vox humana]] [[w:Organ stop|stop]] on a church organ. This stop uses a [[w:Tremulant|tremulant]] (or tremolant) to achieve a vibrato effect. ''Vox humana'' is Latin for ''Human voice'', so Bloom is justified in saying that, ''he knew how to make that instrument talk....'' '''''Stabat Mater'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''The Mother Stood''.Gifford (1988) 95.
Thornton (1968) 85. ''[[w:Stabat Mater|Stabat Mater]]'' are the opening words and traditional title of a 13th-century hymn to the [[w:Virgin Mary|Virgin Mary]]. The hymn is sometimes known as the ''Stabat Mater Dolorosa'' (''The Sorrowful Mother Stood'') to distinguish it from another work with the same opening. It recounts the suffering of Christ's mother during his [[w:Passion (Christianity)|Passion]]. It has been set to music several times. '''''Quis est homo?'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Who is the man?''Gifford (1988) 95.
Thornton (1968) 85. These are the opening words of the third stanza of the ''[[w:Stabat Mater|Stabat Mater]]''. In [[w:Gioachino Rossini|Rossini's]] setting, ''[[w:Stabat Mater (Rossini)|Quis est homo?]]'' is a duet for soprano and mezzo-soprano. '''''Gloria'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Glory''.Gifford (1988) 96.
Thornton (1968) 85. The opening word and traditional title of the hymn ''[[w:Gloria in excelsis Deo|Gloria in excelsis Deo]]'' (''Glory to God in the highest''), the Greater Doxology or Angelic Hymn which forms part of the [[w:Order of Mass|Ordinary]] of the [[w:Tridentine Mass|Latin Mass]]. The ''Gloria'' in the spurious ''Mozart's Twelfth Mass'' is still a popular piece with amateur choirs.[http://www.youtube.com/results?search_query=Mozart%27s+Twelfth+Mass&oq=Mozart%27s+Twelfth+Mass&aq=f&aqi=&aql=&gs_sm=e&gs_upl=3675l16055l0l16581l21l21l0l15l15l0l172l828l1.5l6l0 YouTube] ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Lotus_Eaters/078|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Lotus_Eaters/080|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

page.title: Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Lotus Eaters/081

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=84]]
==Annotations== '''Aq. Dist. Fol. Laur. Te Virid.'''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin abbreviations'') ''[[wikt:aqua|Aqua]] [[wikt:distillata|Distillata]]. [[wikt:folia|Folia]] [[wikt:lauri|Lauri]]. Thea [[wikt:viridis|Viridis]].'' (''Distilled Water. Laurel Leaves. Green Tea.)''Gifford (1988) 98. Bloom is reading some of the labels on the apothecary's jars of ingredients. Several of these and similar jars are still on display in Sweny's Chemist. [[w:Distilled water|Distilled water]] is used by pharmacists as a [[w:diluent|diluent]].[http://www.ripplefxwater.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=18&Itemid=32 Distilled Water in Pharmacy.] Leaves of the [[w:Bay leaf|bay laurel]] (''Laurus nobilis'') have several medicinal uses.[http://medicineherbs.net/medicinal-herbs/laurel Laurel.] ''Thea viridis'' L. is one of the older scientific names for the Chinese tea herb from which [[w:green tea|green tea]] is made. ''[[w:Camellia sinensis|Camellia sinensis]]'' is the currently preferred name. It too has medicinal uses.[http://medicineherbs.net/medicinal-herbs/green-tea Green Tea.] Is Joyce's ''Te'' an error for ''The.''? '''''Peau d'Espagne'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''Spanish skin''.Gifford (1988) 98. ''[[w:Peau d'Espagne|Peau d'Espagne]]'' is a perfume made of flower and spice oils. Presumably Bloom is mentally answering Martha Clifford's inquiry concerning Molly's perfume. In ''[[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Penelope/713|Penelope]]'', Molly will recall using a cheap and inferior form of ''Peau d'Espagne'' when she was living with her father in Gibraltar. ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Lotus_Eaters/080|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Lotus_Eaters/082|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=88]]
==Annotations== '''''fidus Achates'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''faithful Achates''.Gifford (1988) 105.
Thornton (1968) 90. [[w:Achates|Achates]] is the friend and companion of [[w:Aeneas|Aeneas]] in [[w:Virgil|Virgil's]] epic poem the ''[[w:Aeneid|Aeneid]]''. He is referred to by this phrase on three occasions. In the context of an episode called ''Hades'', the most relevant instance occurs at ''Aeneid'' 6:158, shortly before Aeneas descends into the Underworld.[http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.02.0054%3Abook%3D6%3Acard%3D156 ''Aeneid'' 6:156-182] ''Achates'' has become a by-word for an intimate companion, though the name is often used ironically. In English ''fidus Achates'' is pronounced [ˈfaɪdəs æˈkeɪtiːz]. ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''

revision.comment: /* Performance benchmarks */ Added link to OC Blog article
revision.text:
The performance of OpenClinica as an application is dependent upon numerous software, load and hardware variables - those on the client's machine, in the network and on the server. This page is intended as a guide to where these issues can be explored.
== The effect of CRF size == The speed of CRF pages can be affected by the number of fields in a section (also known as a tab or page). Long sections download slowly due to the fact that for each item in the active section, several pieces of javascript must be downloaded and parsed. If a CRF is split into two or more sections than this improves the loading speed of the CRF considerably.
The download speed of a large section can also be improved if a reverse proxy (see below) is used to compress the page.
== The client machine == A client machine that is slow or that is running complex programs in parallel with the web browser can result in the web pages displaying slowly. The client machine's net connection may also be problematic if the machine if connected via an unstable wireless connection.
== The network == The further the client machine is away from the server and the worse the network connection, the longer communication will take between the two, to transmit even small pages and simple graphics. Having the server halfway around the world from the client (e.g. a client in Australia and the server in the UK) can add 1/3rd of a second to communication time (that's 2/3rds second for a round trip).
== The server == === Server software === The server uses a number of pieces of software to respond to clients, which respond reasonably well in the default configuration, but can be optimised in different ways:
*OpenClinica ** [http://blog.openclinica.com/2012/12/03/openclinica-3-1-3-now-available/ Recent versions of OpenClinica] include performance optimisations, including '40% faster turn times' on an optimised system (read a related [https://mailman.openclinica.com/pipermail/users/2012-December/007946.html discussion]) ** OpenClinica has no configuration for performance optimisation (though there is a [[OpenClinica_User_Manual/PageAnalysis|'wishlist']] for further improvements). If OpenClinica is running smoothly, the amount of time it spends writing data to the logs can be reduced. Warning: only do this when you experience no problems! In the datainfo.properties, under '''11 - Logging configuration''' change the entry '''logLevel''' to '''logLevel = warn''' or for the brave among us to '''logLevel = error'''. As soon as anything unusual happens, changed it back to '''info'''. *Tomcat - the OpenClinica documentation describes how to install Tomcat, which serves up web pages. Tomcat can be optimised: **See OpenClinica's optimisation instructions for [https://docs.openclinica.com/3.1/installation/installation-linux#content-title-5460 Linux] or for [https://docs.openclinica.com/3.1/installation/installing-openclinica-windows#content-title-5461 Windows] **[[OpenClinica_User_Manual/UsingAReverseProxy|Compression (and SSL) can be enabled on Tomcat itself]] without using a reverse proxy **Other software can be used to augment Tomcat in at least a couple of ways: ***Installing a reverse proxy such as Nginx (see [[OpenClinica_User_Manual/UsingAReverseProxy|Using Nginx as a secure reverse proxy for OpenClinica]]) to deal with SSL, content caching and compression. ***Installing Tomcat/Apache's [http://tomcat.apache.org/tomcat-6.0-doc/apr.html APR] to speed up SSL. *Database - for Postgresql see [[OpenClinica_User_Manual/OptimisingPostgreSQL|Optimising PostgreSQL]]. Alternatively, [http://docs.oracle.com/ Oracle's docs] have sections on optimisation
When a server is configured optimally (with sufficient memory allocated as in the references above), [https://mailman.openclinica.com/pipermail/users/2012-December/007946.html this thread] suggests OpenClinica is primarily limited by the performance of Postgres' caching, and the speed of the processor it runs on. Further improvements might be gained by optimisations to OpenClinica itself.
=== Server hardware === ==== Minimal ==== See the [https://community.openclinica.com/project/openclinica#systemreqs Compatibility and System Requirements section of the Download OpenClinica page] in the OpenClinica documentation for basic hardware server requirements.
==== Working ==== OpenClinica have a page on [https://docs.openclinica.com/3.1/technical-documents/hardware-software-stack-considerations Hardware & Software Stack Considerations] that suggests a 'base configuration that works well' of: Quad Core Xeon Processor 2.0Ghz or better, 4 GB RAM, 4 x 73 GB HD. This is the same specification referred to in a mail in November 2011 by an OpenClinica employee on what he considered a [https://mailman.openclinica.com/pipermail/users/2011-November/006112.html 'a pretty nice setup to run OpenClinica on']. He highlighted the speed of the disk array as a key factor in performance.
==== Optimal ==== OpenClinica Optimized(tm) Hosting ([http://blog.openclinica.com/2011/10/07/clinical-trials-cloud/ Clinical Trials in the Cloud]) is architected by Shaun Martin (see the [https://www.openclinica.com/new-cloud-enabled-openclinica-optimized%E2%84%A2-hosting-raises-bar-openclinica-performance-and-reliabilit-0 press release]), and uses Fusion-io's hybrid disk technology (see below) and multiple redundancy.
==== The theory ==== *Memory requirements: As of OpenClinica 3.1.x, Tomcat can use up to 2GB of RAM (see server software section above), a PostgreSQL database can use up to 2GB of RAM (see [[OpenClinica_User_Manual/OptimisingPostgreSQL|Optimising PostgreSQL]]) and Oracle's requirements vary. *Disk space requirements: The space taken up by the application and PostgreSQL are around 1GB (Oracle's requirements will vary). Tomcat consumes about 400MB of disk space, and each Tomcat instance takes up around 100MB of space (assuming CRFs don't include uploaded file attachments). Java consumes about 250MB of space, and PostgreSQL 250MB of space. Actual data entry will increase usage, but as the data is generally text (except in the case of CRF file attachements), the space used is unlikely to be huge. *Disk speed requirements: Faster disks, such as SSDs (solid state disks) and high speed hard disks will speed up the response times of PostgreSQL or Oracle. **For example, OpenClinica Optimized(tm) Hosting ([http://blog.openclinica.com/2011/10/07/clinical-trials-cloud/ Clinical Trials in the Cloud]) uses Fusion-io's hybrid disk technology (SSDs in combination with regular hard disks) to improve database performance - 'data extracts run up to 10x faster'. **In a posting to the OpenClinica user list about testing SSDs, Michael Bluett reported that SSDs [https://mailman.openclinica.com/pipermail/users/2012-December/007946.html "didn't seem to give any benefit"] on an optimised system, with Marco van Zwetselaar suggesting that this might be due to 'having plenty of memory (and allocating it to PostgreSQL), which would then mostly operate from its cache'. **In a posting to the OpenClinica user list about starting to use SSDs, Krister Kristianson reported faster performance, that [https://mailman.openclinica.com/pipermail/users/2012-January/006588.html 'What took up to 10 seconds now takes less than 1 second']. **When reporting a slow page in issuetracker, 'dannyl' reported a 2.5-3x speed increase, saying that the SSD [https://issuetracker.openclinica.com/view.php?id=12197#c42215 'has dropped response time to about 8-10s instead of 20-30s'] (login required). *Processor requirements: Faster processors with more cores will speed up the generation of pages by Tomcat, PostgreSQL and Oracle. If the server software is optimised and [https://mailman.openclinica.com/pipermail/users/2012-December/007946.html pages and data mostly served from cache], then a faster processor may be the best way to improve the server's contribution to the response time *Separate web server and database server: Separating the database server (Postgresql/Oracle) from the webserver (Tomcat) may spread the load of the server if a single server is seen to be overloaded. But this separation introduces networking delays, which may outweigh the benefits if the webserver is frequently communicating with the database server. As a possible warning, [https://issuetracker.openclinica.com/view.php?id=12197 a bug with version 3.1.2] (login required) describes a large number of queries to the database being made by tomcat.
=== Performance benchmarks === OpenClinica provide [https://docs.openclinica.com/customer-docs/openclinica-performance-benchmarks OpenClinica Performance Benchmarks](Link broken) to set your expectation of how fast an instance should respond in the real world. The article [http://blog.openclinica.com/2013/03/27/openclinica-3-1-3-community-version-performance-test-on-hdd-vs-ssd/ OpenClinica 3.1.3 Community Version – Performance Test on HDD vs. SSD] from the OpenClinica Blog lists some performance benchmarks.
==Measuring and analysing performance==
Performance can be measured from the browser and remotely, highlighting the cause of any delay - is it processing on the server, or the speed of data from the server to the client?
*Browser add-ons can analyse the performance of a web site from a client's browser (as well as the performance of individual pages): [http://developer.yahoo.com/yslow/ YSlow] and [http://code.google.com/speed/page-speed/ Page Speed]
*Sites such as [http://www.webpagetest.org/ webpagetest.org] and [http://tools.pingdom.com/ tools.pingdom.com] may be used to test the speed of your website from various points on the web.
==Further reading== Web application optimization is a complex and almost open-ended topic (see [http://www.google.com/search?q=factors+in+web+application+performance]).
{{BookCat}}

==Annotations== '''''Madame'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''Madam'', a title or form of address for a married woman. '''''voglio e non vorrei''. No : ''vorrei e non.'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Italian'') ''I want to and I wouldn't like to. No : I would like to and [I would] not [like to].''Gifford (1988) 109.
Thornton (1968) 92. Bloom corrects his earlier mistake, though he will later repeat the mistake. See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Calypso/061|061.33]]. '''''Mi trema un poco il'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Italian'') ''My [heart] is aflutter a little''.Gifford (1988) 109.
Thornton (1968) 92. ''Mi trema un poco il cor'' is the next line Zerlina sings after ''Vorrei e non vorrei''. See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Calypso/061|061.33]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 26%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''

revision.comment: Created page with "[http://onlineseoservices.net/ seo services] & coderPreparation: It's good to start preparing for the job as early as high school. Taking courses in math (since you will be de..."
revision.text: [http://onlineseoservices.net/ seo services] & coderPreparation: It's good to start preparing for the job as early as high school. Taking courses in math (since you will be dealing with numbers on a daily basis) and science (to get familiarized with medical terminology) will help you make a smooth transition into post-secondary [http://medicalassistantschoolsinfo.com/#x-ray-technician/ x ray technician] . You should also look to build your computer and communication skills while in high school.Training: [http://onlineseoservices.net/#link-building-services/ link building services] in Allied Health or [http://bestmedicalassistantjobs.com/#medical assistants medical assistants] or a Bachelor's degree in Health Information Systems are options you can consider if you have the time and budget for a college education. Self-paced online [http://lytecmedicalbillingsoftware.com/#medical-billing-from-home medical billing from home] are also available.Certification: Although certification is not a prerequisite for employment, it helps add weight to a [http://lytecmedicalbillingsoftware.com/#medical-billers how to become a medical biller] CV. A resume adorned with certification from organizations like the American Health Information Management Association (AHIMA) or American Academy of Professional Coders (AAPC) will have a much higher potential to secure a job with proper [http://lytecmedicalbillingsoftware.com/#medical-billers medical biller].

==Annotations== '''''Mater Misericordiæ'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Mother of Mercy''. The [[w:Mater Misericordiæ University Hospital|Mater Misericordiæ University Hospital]], popularly known as the Mater, was the largest hospital in Dublin in 1904.Gifford (1988) 113. Located on the corner of Eccles Street, it was founded in 1861. '''Ward for incurables there.'''{{spaces|5}}The Mater Misericordiæ hospital did have a ward for incurables in 1904.Gifford (1988) 113. ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=103]]
==Annotations== '''''Dominenamine'''''{{spaces|5}}Bloom has either misheard or deliberately mangled the priest's ''In nomine Domini'' (Latin: ''In the name of the Lord''), possibly conflating it with the final syllable of Paddy Dignam's name.Gifford (1988) 117.
Thornton (1968) 98. In the Roman Rite the [[w:Absolution of the dead|Absolution of the Dead]] was said over the deceased following [[w:Requiem Mass|Requiem Mass]] and before the burial. Joyce omits Dignam's Requiem (is this artistic licence, or was this an acceptable practice in Dublin in 1904?), but the Absolution begins without preamble with the prayer beginning ''Non intres ....'' So it is possible that Bloom is merely improvising.[http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/03071a.htm Catholic Encyclopedia.] '''''Non intres in judicium cum servo tuo, Domine.'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Enter not into judgment with thy servant, O Lord.''Gifford (1988) 118.
Thornton (1968) 99. These are the opening words of the prayer, based on Psalms 143,[http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Psalms%20143&version=KJV Psalms 143 (Vulgate 142).] that begins the Absolution of the Dead: {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''Non Intres'''''[http://www.archive.org/stream/ritualeromanumpa00cath#page/193/mode/1up ''Rituale Romanum''] |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ''Lord, do not call your servant to account; for no one can stand guiltless in your presence unless you grant him forgiveness of all his sins. Therefore, we pray, that in passing judgment you will not let your sentence fall heavily on one who is commended to you by the sincere prayer of Christian faith. But with the help of your grace may this servant, who during life was sealed with the sign of the Blessed Trinity, be found worthy of escaping the doom of your vengeance. We ask this of you who live and reign forever and ever.'' ''Amen'' | ''Non intres in judicium cum servo tuo, Domine, quia nullus apud te justificabitur homo, nisi per te omnium peccatoru ei tribuatur remissio. Non ergo eum, quæsumus, tua judicialis sententia premat, quem tibi vera supplicatio fidei christianæ commendat. Sed gratia tua illi succurrente, mereatur, evadere judicium ultionis, qui dum viveret, insgnitus est signaculo sanctæ Trinitatis: Qui vivis et regnas in sæcula sæculorum.'' ''Amen.'' |} '''''Et ne nos inducas in tentationem.'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''And lead us not into temptation.'' These words are taken from the [[w:Lord's Prayer|Lord's Prayer]] (Matthew 6:13 and Luke 2:4). After the ''Non Intres'', the Absolution of the Dead continues with the responsory ''[[w:Libera Me|Libera Me]]'' (''Deliver Me'') and the ''[[w:Kyrie|Kyrie Eleison]]'' (''Lord, Have Mercy''). The priest then intones aloud the opening two words of the Lord's Prayer: ''Pater Noster'' (''Our Father''). As the following lines are being recited silently, the priest sprinkles the bier with holy water with the [[w:Aspergillum|aspersorium]] and incenses the body with the [[w:thurible|thurible]]. When he has completed these tasks, the Lord's Prayer is resumed with the following responsory and prayer: {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''Et Ne Nos Inducas'''''[http://www.archive.org/stream/ritualeromanumpa00cath#page/197/mode/1up ''Rituale Romanum''.]
[http://www.sanctamissa.org/en/resources/books-1962/rituale-romanum/43-burial-of-adults.html Sancta Missa.] |- style="vertical-align: top;" | '''P:''' ''And lead us not into temptation.''
'''All:''' ''But deliver us from evil.''
'''P:''' ''From the gates of hell.''
'''All:''' ''Deliver his soul, O Lord.''
'''P:''' ''May he rest in peace.''
'''All:''' ''Amen.''
'''P:''' ''Lord, heed my prayer.''
'''All:''' ''And let my cry be heard by you.''
'''P:''' ''The Lord be with you.''
'''All:''' ''And with your spirit.''

'''P:''' ''Let us pray. God, whose nature is ever merciful and forgiving, we humbly entreat you for the soul of your servant, Patrick, who at your bidding has today departed this world; do not deliver him into the enemy's hands, or put him out of mind forever, but bid your holy angels to welcome him and lead him home to Paradise. Let him not undergo the pains of hell, for he put his hope and trust in you, but let him have the joy that knows no ending; through Christ our Lord.''

'''All:''' ''Amen.''
| '''V:''' ''Et ne nos inducas in tentationem.''
'''R:''' ''Sed libera nos a malo.''
'''V:''' ''A porta inferi.''
'''R:''' ''Erue, Domine, animam eius.''
'''V:''' ''Requiescat in pace.''
'''R:''' ''Amen.''
'''V:''' ''Domine, exaudi orationem meam.''
'''R:''' ''Et clamor meus ad te veniat.''
'''V:''' ''Dominus vobiscum.''
'''R:''' ''Et cum spiritu tuo.''

'''V:''' ''Oremus. Deus, cui proprium est misereri semper, et parcere: te supplices exoramus pro anima famuli tui Patricii, quam hodie de hoc sæculo migrare iussisti: ut non tradas eam in manus inimici, neque obliviscaris in finem, sed iubeas eam a sanctis Angelis suscipi et ad patriam Paradisi perduci: ut, quia in te speravit et credidit, non pœnas inferni sustineat, sed gaudia sempiterna possideat. Per Christum Dominum nostrum.''

'''R:''' ''Amen.'' |} '''''In paradisum.'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Into Paradise.''Gifford (1988) 118.
Thornton (1968) 99. These are the opening words of the [[w:In paradisum|antiphon]] which the clergy now sing as the coffin is being taken from the mortuary church: {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''In Paradisum'''''[http://www.archive.org/stream/ritualeromanumpa00cath#page/198/mode/1up ''Rituale Romanum''.]
[http://www.sanctamissa.org/en/resources/books-1962/rituale-romanum/43-burial-of-adults.html Sancta Missa.] |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ''May the angels lead you into Paradise. May the martyrs receive you at your coming, and take you to Jerusalem, the holy city. May the choir of angels be there to welcome you. And may you, with the once poor Lazarus, have everlasting rest.'' | ''In paradisum deducant te Angeli. In tuo adventu suscipiant te martyres, et perducant te in civitatem sanctam Ierusalem. Chorus angelorum te suscipiat. Et cum Lazaro quondam paupere æternam habeas requiem.'' |} See also [[s:The_Tragedy_of_Hamlet,_Prince_of_Denmark|''Hamlet'' 5:2:364-365:]] ''Good night, sweet prince, And flights of angels sing thee to thy rest.'' ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Hades/099|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Hades/101|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=108]]
==Annotations== '''''De mortuis nil nisi prius.'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Of the dead [speak] nothing but before.''Gifford (1988) 121.
Thornton (1968) 101. Bloom is misquoting the Latin apothegm ''[[w:De mortuis nil nisi bonum|De mortuis nil nisi bonum]]'' (''Of the dead [speak] nothing but good''). He may be trying to adapt the saying to the idea he expresses in the same line, the implication being that one must wait at least two years ''before'' speaking ill of the dead. He is probably also remembering vaguely the legal term ''[[w:Nisi prius|nisi prius]]'' (''unless previously''), which refers to the court of original jurisdiction that heard a case as distinguished from a court of appeals. ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Hades/104|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Hades/106|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=109]]
==Annotations== '''Last act of ''Lucia. Shall I nevermore behold thee?'' Bam! expires'''{{spaces|5}}''[[wikt:Lucia di Lammermoor|Lucia di Lammermoor]]'' (1835) is an opera in three acts by [[wikt:Gaetano Donizetti|Gaetano Donizetti]] after [[wikt:Walter Scott|Walter Scott's]] novel ''[[wikt:The Bride of Lammermoor|The Bride of Lammermoor]]'' (1819).Gifford (1988) 122.
Thornton (1968) 103. The plot, similar to that of ''Romeo and Juliet'', concerns the tragic love of Lucia Ashton and Edgardo di Ravenswood, whose families are engaged in a deadly feud. In the final scene, when Edgardo has learned that Lucia is dying and has called for him, he sings: {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''Lucia di Lammermoor'''''[http://www.dlib.indiana.edu/variations/scores/bhq5367/large/index.html ''Lucia di Lammermoor''.] |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ''Rivederla ancor vogli' io,'' ''Revederla e poscia....'' | ''I want to see her again,'' ''See her again and then....'' |} But just as Edgardo is about to rush to Lucia's side, he is detained by the Calvinist chaplain Raimondo Bidebent, who informs him that Lucia is dead. As is often the case, Bloom's memory has let him down. Edgardo does not expire after this line — his lamentations go one for several more minutes before he stabs himself and dies. What is more, Bloom's ''translation'' of the foregoing line is inaccurate. He seems to be confusing the aria with the refrain from [[wikt:Stephen Foster|Stephen Foster's]] song ''[[wikt:Gentle Annie (song)|Gentle Annie]]'' (1856): ''Shall we never more behold thee''.[http://imslp.org/wiki/Gentle_Annie_%28Foster,_Stephen%29 Stephen Foster, ''Gentle Annie''.] ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 26%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Hades/105|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Hades/107|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=118]]
==Annotations== '''Nannan'''{{spaces|5}}Nickname for Joseph Nannetti, MP for Dublin College Green (1901-1915).[http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/people/mr-joseph-nannetti/ Mr Joseph Nannetti (Hansard).] See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Cyclops/302|302.25]]. ==References== {| style="width: 26%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Aeolus/114|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Aeolus/116|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=121]]
==Annotations== '''that brought us out of the land of Egypt and into the house of bondage'''{{spaces|5}}Bloom misremembers (or is he being intentionally ironic?) a phrase that occurs several times in the ''[[wikt:Haggadah|Haggadah]]'', the text Jews recite at the start of the feast of [[wikt:Passover Seder|Passover]], when they celebrate the events recounted in the [[wikt:Exodus|Book of Exodus ]].Gifford (1988) 132.
Thornton (1968) 110. The words are taken from Exodus 13:3 and 13:14.[http://www.mechon-mamre.org/p/pt/pt0213.htm#3 Exodus 13:3] and [http://www.mechon-mamre.org/p/pt/pt0213.htm#14 Exodus 13:14.] '''''alleluia'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Praise God!''Gifford (1988) 132.
Thornton (1968) 110. This is the usual Latin form of the Hebrew command ''[[wikt:Hallelujah|Hallelu Yah]]'', or ''Hallelujah''. The word occurs several times in the ''[[wikt:Haggadah|Haggadah]]'', which Jews read during the celebration of [[wikt:Passover|Passover]]. '''''Shema Israel Adonai Elohenu'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Hebrew'') ''Hear, O Israel, the Lord is our God''.Gifford (1988) 132.
Thornton (1968) 110. These are the opening words of [[wikt:Deuteronomy|Deuteronomy 6:4]], the Hebrew prayer known as the ''Shema'' or ''[[wikt:Shema Yisrael|Shema Yisrael]]''.[http://www.mechon-mamre.org/p/pt/pt0506.htm#4 Deuteronomy 6:4.] This Judaic confession of faith is recited twice a day, morning and evening, by orthodox Jews as part of their daily [[wikt:Jewish prayer|prayer services]]. The Hebrew word ''[[wikt:Names of God in Judaism|Adonai]]'' (''Lord'') is substituted for the Bible's ''YHWH'', which is never pronounced. '''No, that's the other'''{{spaces|5}}Bloom correctly remembers that the ''Shema'' is not part of the Jewish Passover ritual. ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 26%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Aeolus/117|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Aeolus/119|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=127]]
==Annotations== '''''Pardon, monsieur'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''Excuse me, sir''. Lenehan is noted for his frequent use of French. Joyce's principal model for Lenehan was Michael Hart, a friend's of Joyce's father who died around 1900; Hart too had a habit of speaking French.Ellmann (1982), p. 365 See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Ithaca/657|657.20]], where Bloom recalls the death of Hart. '''''anno Domini'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''in the year of our Lord''.Gifford (1988) 136. Lenehan is using the phrase ''[[w:Anno Domini|Anno Domini]]'' in a Pickwickian sense, meaning ''years''. ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Aeolus/123|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Aeolus/125|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=129]]
==Annotations== '''''Thanky vous'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') Lenehan whimsically turns ''Thank you'' into French by translating ''you'' (''[[wikt:vous|vous]]'') and replacing ''Thank'' with a French-sounding hypocorism. The phrase does also sound like the German equivalent, ''[[wikt:danke schön|Danke schön]]'', though Lenehan has no history of quoting German. '''''Imperium romanum'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''The Roman Empire''.Gifford (1988) 137. '''Cloacae'''{{spaces|5}}''Sewers''; ''drains''. The word is the plural of the Latin ''[[wikt:cloaca|cloaca]]''. In some versions of ''Ulysses'' the word is emended to the italicized ''Cloacae'' or the unitalicized "Cloacæ", but the word has been adopted into English, with its Latin plural, so no emendation is required. When an earlier draft of this episode was published in ''[[w:The Little Rewiew|The Little Review]]'' in October 1918, the word ''was'' italicized: ''Cloacae''.[http://dl.lib.brown.edu/repository2/repoman.php?verb=render&id=1298921533562502&view=pageturner&pageno=39 ''The Little Review'', Volume 5, Number 6, Page 37.] ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Aeolus/125|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Aeolus/127|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=131]]
==Annotations== '''''Dominus!'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Lord!''Gifford (1988) 138. Some versions of ''Ulysses'' emend this to the [[w:Vocative case|vocative]] ''[[wikt:Domine|Domine!]]'' '''KYRIE ELEISON'''{{spaces|5}}(''Greek'') ''O Lord, have mercy''.Gifford (1988) 139.
Thornton (1968) 116. ''[[w:Kyrie|Kyrie eleison]]'' is a Latin tranliteration of a Greek prayer, the only piece of Greek to be retained in the [[w:Christian liturgy|Christian liturgy]]. In the [[w:Tridentine Mass|Latin Tridentine Mass]], which was still performed in 1904, the ''Kyrie'' was said or sung between the ''[[w:Introit|Introit]]'' and the ''[[w:Gloria|Gloria]]''. '''''Kyrios'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Greek'') ''Lord''.Gifford (1988) 139. This is a Latin transliteration of the Greek ''[[wikt:Κύριος|Κύριος]]''. '''''Kyrie'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Greek'') ''O Lord'', the vocative case of ''Kyrios''. This is a Latin transliteration of the Greek ''[[wikt:κύριε|κύριε]]''. '''''Kyrie eleison'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Greek'') See '''KYRIE ELEISON''' above. ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Aeolus/127|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Aeolus/129|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=132]]
==Annotations== '''''imperium'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''empire''; ''imperial government''.Gifford (1988) 139.
[[wikt:imperium|Imperium]]. MacHugh is contrasting a spiritual empire with a political one. '''''matinée'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') A theatrical performance taking place in the afternoon. Lenehan, as usual, cannot resist using a French term, though ''[[wikt:matinée|matinée]]'' is now a naturalized English word. ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Aeolus/128|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Aeolus/130|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=133]]
==Annotations== '''OMNIUM GATHERUM'''{{spaces|5}}(''Dog Latin'') An [[w:omnium-gatherum|omnium-gatherum]] is a confused collection of persons or things of various sorts, a hotchpotch. The expression is [[w:Dog Latin|Dog Latin]], comprising an imaginary neuter noun ''gatherum'' (''a gathering'') and the genitive plural ''[[wikt:omnium|omnium]]'' (''of everyone''). '''on the shaughraun'''{{spaces|5}}(''Hiberno-English'') ''Out of work''.Gifford (1988) 140. ''[[wikt:shaughraun|Shaughraun]]'' is an Anglicized form of the Irish ''seachrán'', which means: ''wandering, straying; error, deception, delusion''. ''Ar seachrán'' (''On [the] shaughraun'') can mean: ''wandering, astray, out of work''.[http://glg.csisdmz.ul.ie/index.php?mobile_display=false Dinneen (1934) 995.] ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Aeolus/129|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Aeolus/131|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Aeolus/131|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Aeolus/133|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=136]]
==Annotations== '''''la tua pace ... si tace'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Italian'') Stephen recalls the closing words of lines 92 and 94 and all of line 96 in Canto 5 of [[w:Dante Alighieri|Dante's]] ''[[w:Inferno (Dante)|Inferno]]'':Gifford (1988) 143.
Thornton (1968) 120-121. {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''Inferno'' 5:88-96''' |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ''"O animal grazïoso e benigno'' ''che visitando vai per l’aere perso'' ''noi che tignemmo il mondo di sanguigno,'' ''se fosse amico il re dell’universo,'' ''noi pregheremmo lui de la tua pace,'' ''poi c’hai pietà del nostro mal perverso.'' ''Di quel che udire e che parlar vi piace,'' ''noi udiremo e parleremo a vui,'' ''mentre che ’l vento, come fa, ci tace.'' | ''"O creature gracious and benign,'' ''Who goest through the murky air, visiting'' ''Us, who stained the world with blood,'' ''If the king of the universe were a friend,'' ''We would pray to him for your peace,'' ''Since thou hast pity on our evil plight.'' ''Of that which it pleases thee to hear and speak'' ''We shall hear and speak to thee,'' ''Whilst the wind, as it is, is silent.'' |} The speakers are the adulterers [[w:Paolo Malatesta|Paolo Malatesta]] and [[w:Francesca da Rimini|Francesca da Rimini]]. Joyce's ''. . . .mentreche'' has been emended to ''Mentre che'' in Gabler's corrected text.Gabler (1984) 114. '''He saw them three by three ... underdarkneath the night'''{{spaces|5}}Following the allusion to Dante's ''Inferno'', Stephen now conflates two episodes from the remaining parts of the ''[[w:Divine Comedy|Divine Comedy]]'': the Divine Pageant (or Mystic Procession) in the 29th canto of the ''[[w:Purgatorio|Purgatorio]]'', and the vision of the [[w:Mary (mother of Jesus)|Virgin Mary]] in the 31st canto of the ''[[w:Paradiso (Dante)|Paradiso]]''.Gifford (1988) 143.
Thornton (1968) 121. {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''Purgatorio'' 29:121-135''' |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ''Tre donne in giro da la destra rota'' ''venian danzando; l'una tanto rossa'' ''ch'a pena fora dentro al foco nota;'' ''l'altr'era come se le carni e l'ossa'' ''fossero state di smeraldo fatte;'' ''la terza parea neve teste' mossa;'' ''e or parean da la bianca tratte,'' ''or da la rossa; e dal canto di questa'' ''l'altre toglien l'andare e tarde e ratte.'' ''Da la sinistra quattro facean festa,'' ''in porpore vestite, dietro al modo'' ''d'una di lor ch'avea tre occhi in testa.'' ''Appresso tutto il pertrattato nodo'' ''vidi due vecchi in abito dispari,'' ''ma pari in atto e onesto e sodo.'' | ''Three ladies in a ring at the right wheel'' ''came dancing; one so red'' ''that scarcely would she have been noticed in the fire;'' ''the next was as though her flesh and bones'' ''had been made of emerald;'' ''the third seemed snow newly fallen;'' ''and now they seemed to be led by the white,'' ''now by the red; and from the song of this one'' ''the others took their pace, both slow and fast.'' ''On the left four made festival,'' ''in purple clothed, after the manner'' ''of one of them, who had three eyes in her head.'' ''Behind the whole of the aforementioned knot'' ''I saw two old men in disparate habits,'' ''but alike in their actions both honest and solid.'' |} {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''Paradiso'' 31:124-142''' |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ''E come quivi ove s’aspetta il temo'' ''che mal guidò Fetonte, più s’infiamma,'' ''e quinci e quindi il lume si fa scemo,'' ''così quella pacifica oriafiamma'' ''nel mezzo s’avvivava, e d’ogne parte'' ''per igual modo allentava la fiamma;'' ''e a quel mezzo, con le penne sparte,'' ''vid’ io più di mille angeli festanti,'' ''ciascun distinto di fulgore e d’arte.'' ''Vidi a lor giochi quivi e a lor canti'' ''ridere una bellezza, che letizia'' ''era ne li occhi a tutti li altri santi;'' ''e s’io avessi in dir tanta divizia'' ''quanta ad imaginar, non ardirei'' ''lo minimo tentar di sua delizia.'' ''Bernardo, come vide li occhi miei'' ''nel caldo suo calor fissi e attenti,'' ''li suoi con tanto affetto volse a lei,'' ''che ’ miei di rimirar fé più ardenti.'' | ''And as the place where one awaits the shaft'' ''that [[w:Phaëton|Phaëton]] ill guided is most inflamed,'' ''while on this side and on that the light abates,'' ''so that peaceful Oriflamme'' ''was rekindled in the middle, while on each side'' ''in equal measure the flame weakened;'' ''and at that middle, with their wings displayed,'' ''I saw more than a thousand jubilant angels,'' ''each one distinct in splendour and in skill.'' ''I saw, at their games there and at their songs'' ''smiling, a beautiful one, who joy'' ''was in the eyes of all the other saints;'' ''and if I had in speech as much abundance divizia'' ''as in imagination, I would not dare'' ''attempt the least of her delights.'' ''[[w:Bernard of Clairvaux|Bernard]], as soon as he saw my eyes'' ''on her warm heat fixed and attentive,'' ''his own with such affection he turned to her'' ''that he made mine more eager to regaze.'' |} '''He saw them three by three'''{{spaces|5}}[[w:Dante Alighieri|Dante]], who employed ''[[w:Terza rima|terza rima]]'' in his ''[[w:Divine Comedy|Divine Comedy]]''. '''three by three'''{{spaces|5}}This phrase does not occur in the passages Stephen conflates. GiffordGifford (1988) 143. mistranslates ''Purgatorio'' 29:110 ''tre e tre'' as ''three by three'', believing it refers to the three approaching ladies, but ''tre e tre'' means ''three and three'', and refers to the first three and final three of the seven bands in the Divine Pageant: twenty-four elders, representing the books of the [[w:Old Testament|Old Testament]]; the four [[w:Living creatures (Bible)|Living Creatures of the Apocalypse]], representing the four [[w:Gospel|Gospels]]; the three ladies, representing the three [[w:Theological virtues|Theological Virtues]], Faith, Hope and Charity; four dancers, representing the four [[w:Cardinal virtues|Cardinal Virtues]], Prudence, Justice, Temperance and Fortitude; two old men, representing the ''[[w:Acts of the Apostles|Acts of the Apostles]]'' and the [[w:Pauline epistles|Epistles of Saint Paul]]; four humble men, representing the [[w:General epistles|Epistles of Saints Peter, James, John and Jude]]; and one old man, representing the ''[[w:Book of Revelation|Book of Revelation]]''. Stephen, however, is still thinking of the ''[[w:terza rima|terza rima]]'' Dante employs in his ''Comedy'', in which the rhymes occur three by three. '''entwining'''{{spaces|5}}Stephen is thinking of the manner in which the rhymes are entwined in Dante's ''[[w:Terza rima|terza rima]]''. '''''per l'aere perso'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Italian'') ''through the murky air''. In his ''[[w:Convivio|Convivio]]'', Dante defines ''perse'' as ''a colour mingled of purple and of black, but the black predominates''.[http://archive.org/stream/convivioofdantea00dantiala#page/325/mode/1up Dante, ''Convivio'' 4:20.] See the quotation from Dante's ''Inferno'' 5:89 above. '''''quella pacifica oriafiamma'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Italian'') ''that peaceful Oriflamme''. See the quotation from [[w:Dante Alighieri|Dante's]] ''[[w:Paradiso (Dante)|Paradiso]]'' 31:127 above. The ''[[w:Oriflamme|Oriflamme]]'' was the battle standard of the kings of France. '''''di rimirar fè più ardenti'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Italian'') ''made ''[''my eyes'']'' more eager to regaze''. See the quotation from [[w:Dante Alighieri|Dante's]] ''[[w:Paradiso (Dante)|Paradiso]]'' 31:142 above. These are the closing words of the canto. '''But I old men'''{{spaces|5}}Dante saw his rhymes three by three as colourful girls, but Stephen sees the rhymes he employed in the quatrain he wrote in ''Proteus'' as pairs of old men. See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Aeolus/127|127.20-23]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 26%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Aeolus/132|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Aeolus/134|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=137]]
==Annotations== '''ITALIA, MAGISTRA ARTIUM'''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Italy, Mistress of the Arts''.Gifford (1988) 146. There may be an allusion to the [[w:Master of Arts|Master of Arts]] or ''Magister Artium'', a postgraduate degree awarded by universities for excellence in the [[w:humanities|humanities]]. In the Middle Ages the arts in question were the [[w:Seven Liberal Arts|Seven Liberal Arts]], but new subjects were gradually added to the curriculum. '''''lex talionis'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''law of talion''; ''law of retaliation in kind''. The [[wikt:lex talionis|lex talionis]] is the Latin form of the Mosaic principle of ''[[w:Eye for an eye|an eye for an eye and a tooth for a tooth]]'', in which the punishment inflicted upon a criminal is similar to the crime he committed.Gifford (1988) 146.
Thornton (1968) 123.
[http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Exodus%2021&version=KJV Exodus 21:23-25] ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Aeolus/133|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Aeolus/135|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=141]]
==Annotations== '''''Fuit Ilium!'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Troy has been!''Gifford (1988) 150.
Thornton (1968) 126. The quotation is from [[w:Virgil|Virgil's]] epic poem the ''[[w:Aeneid|Aeneid]]'' 2:325: {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''Aeneid'' 2:325-326'''[http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.02.0054%3Abook%3D2%3Acard%3D318 ''Aeneid'']
[http://www.theoi.com/Text/VirgilAeneid2.html H. R. Fairclough's Translation] |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ''...: We Trojans are no more, Ilium is no more, nor the great''
''Glory of the Teucrians;'' | ''...: fuimus Troes, fuit Ilium et ingens''
''Gloria Teucrorum; |} ''[[w:Ilium|Ilium]]'' is a Latinized form of ''Ilion'' (Ἴλιον), another name for the legendary city of Troy, whence the title of Homer's ''Iliad''. The Trojans were sometimes known as ''Teucri'' (''Teucrians'') after [[w:King Teucer|Teucer]], ''earliest ancestor'' of the Trojans.[http://www.theoi.com/Text/VirgilAeneid3.html ''Aeneid'' 3:104 ff.] ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Aeolus/137|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Aeolus/139|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

== Comment on presentation of Rule 110 ==
The information presented is dense. There is not enough explanatory English text. One would need to know a lot about CA in advance in order to make sense of the page? Михал Орела http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/User:MihalOrela 14:05, 24 November 2011 (UTC)
== Garden of Eden regular expression correct? ==
The shortest sequence I can generate with the garden of eden regular expression 0*1(00*1+1(1+00)*010)*1(1+00)*011(0+1)* is 11011
11011 is not a garden of eden state as 1010011 is it's parent.
Also I cannot seem to generate 01010, which does appear to be a garden of eden state as stated, with the regular expression.
Perhaps I am reading the symbols wrong, I am interpreting them with the same meaning they have in POSIX regexes. even if I interpret the plus symbol as a union, I can get 11011 and not 01010. It just seems incorrect to me.
If no one can explain where this regex comes from someone should delete it. Also a citation would be nice, then we could actually verify these things from an authoritative source.
For all I know that could be a regex of garden of eden states for a different rule that got placed here by mistake.

page.title: Talk:Cellular Automata/Examples of Plankton and Fish Dynamics

revision.text:
== Predator-prey dynamics ==
Most of the material is classical mathematics. There are some diagrams at the bottom which are CA-related? The page would NOT ENCOURAGE the inquisitive visitor... One really needs to emphasize the CA up front rather than presenting the classical differential equations? Михал Орела http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/User:MihalOrela 14:14, 24 November 2011 (UTC)
