== This page needs a few things ==
I would love to see examples that include the asymmetrical comparisons, such as the jl operation. It would also be great if "first" and "second" arguments could be more clearly defined. --[[User:Sbluen|Sbluen]] ([[User talk:Sbluen|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Sbluen|contribs]]) 06:36, 6 December 2011 (UTC)
:<s>"First" seems to be arg1 and "second" is arg2, as placed in the CMP instruction syntax in the beginning.</s> ::Actually, on closer inspection, this is incorrect. As it stands, "first" refers to '''arg2''' and "second" refers to '''arg1'''. Pretty confusing. I would prefer to have someone confirm this before making changes, but it would be good to just replace "first" by '''arg2''' and "second" by '''arg1'''. [[Special:Contributions/69.172.83.38|69.172.83.38]] ([[User talk:69.172.83.38|discuss]]) 21:44, 12 December 2012 (UTC) :::Those descriptions need a rewrite, it is on my todo list but please feel free to attempt one. I have been adding code examples in nasm or gas when possible since that can help to fill in holes. revision.text:
== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Roolebo!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks. --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Italy.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 12:47, 27 November 2011 (UTC)

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=345]]
==Annotations== '''''retroussé'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''turned up''. In English this French [[wikt:retroussé|term]] is used to describe the shape of the nose. '''Refuge of sinners. Comfortress of the afflicted. ''Ora pro nobis'''''{{spaces|5}} (''Latin'') ''... Pray for us.''Gifford (1988) 390.
Thornton (1968) 312. From the [[w:Litany of the Blessed Virgin Mary|Litany of Our Lady of Loreto]].[http://www.columbia.edu/cu/augustine/arch/bvm/loretto.html Litany of Loreto.] See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Nausicaa/338|338.31.]] ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=347]]
==Annotations== '''''Tableau!'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''Picture!'' In the theatre, a tableau is a static scene in a play in which the performers hold their positions; the term is also used as the corresponding stage direction. Here, Gerty is using it as an interjection to draw attention to a dramatic scene.[http://www.oed.com/view/Entry/196787?rskey=VyUrg2&result=1 ''Tableau'', Oxford English Dictionary.] According to Gifford, ''Tableau'' was also the name of a parlour game in which participants would create a tableau the meaning of which was to be guessed by the remaining participants; when the pose was complete, one of the participants would cry ''Tableau!''Gifford (1988) 391. See also [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Nausicaa/352|352.19]]. '''''Tantum ergo'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''[[w:Tantum Ergo|Tantum Ergo]]'' is the title and opening words of a hymn comprising the final two stanza's of [[w:Thomas Aquinas|Saint Thomas Aquinas's]] hymn ''[[w:Pange Lingua Gloriosi Corporis Mysterium|Pange Lingua Gloriosi Corporis Mysterium]]''.Gifford (1988) 391-392.
Thornton (1968) 312. It is commonly sung as part of the [[w:Benediction of the Blessed Sacrament|Benediction of the Blessed Sacrament]] {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''Tantum Ergo''''' |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ''Tantum ergo Sacramentum'' ''Veneremur cernui:'' ''Et antiquum documentum'' ''Novo cedat ritui:'' ''Praestet fides supplementum'' ''Sensuum defectui.'' ''Genitori, Genitoque'' ''Laus et jubilatio,'' ''Salus, honor, virtus quoque'' ''Sit et benedictio:'' ''Procedenti ab utroque'' ''Compar sit laudatio.'' | ''Therefore so great a Sacrament'' ''Let us venerate with bowed heads:'' ''And may the old practice'' ''Give way to the new rite:'' ''May faith make up for'' ''The failings of the senses.'' ''To the Begetter and the Begotten'' ''Praise and jubilation,'' ''salutation, honour, virtue also'' ''May there be, and blessing:'' ''To Him who proceeds from both ''May there be equal praise.''The ''Sacrament'' refers to Christ's sacrifice. The ''old practice'' and the ''new rite'' refer to the Old and New [[w:Covenant (biblical)|Covenants]]. The ''Begetter, Begotten'' and ''He who proceeds from both'' are the three persons of the [[w:Trinity|Holy Trinity]]: God the Father, God the Son and God the Holy Spirit. |} '''''Tantumer gosa cramen tum'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') Gerty's rhythmic version of the opening line of the ''Tantum Ergo'' suggests that the syllables ''er'', ''sa'' and ''men'' are set to longer notes than the other syllables. Over the centuries there have been literally hundreds of settings of this hymn, but I have not yet identified which if any matches the rhythm of Gerty's swinging foot.Gifford (1988) 392. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Nausicaa/343|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Nausicaa/345|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=349]]
==Annotations== '''''Panem de coelo praestitisti eis'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''You have given them bread from Heaven.''Gifford (1988) 392.
Thornton (1968) 313. In the [[w:Benediction of the Blessed Sacrament|Benediction of the Blessed Sacrament]], after the singing of the ''[[w:Tantum Ergo|Tantum Ergo]]'', the celebrant recites this versicle, to which the congregation respond: {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |- style="vertical-align: top;" | '''V:''' ''Panem de coelo praestitisti eis.'' '''R:''' ''Omne delectamentum in se habentem.'' | '''V:''' ''You have given them bread from Heaven.'' '''R:''' ''Having all sweetness within it.'' |} ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Nausicaa/345|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Nausicaa/347|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=351]]
==Annotations== '''''Laudate Dominum omnes gentes'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Praise the Lord, all nations.''Gifford (1988) 394.
Thornton (1968) 314-315. At the conclusion of the [[w:Benediction of the Blessed Sacrament|Benediction of the Blessed Sacrament]], as the celebrant is replacing the Sacrament in the tabernacle, the congregation sing an [[w:Antiphon|antiphon]] based on Psalm 117 (Vulgate 116), ''[[w:Laudate Dominum|Laudate Dominum]]'': {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''Psalms 117'''''[http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Psalm%20116&version=VULGATE Psalm 116|117.] |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ''Laudate Dominum, omnes gentes: conlaudate eum, universi populi'' ''Quia confortata est super nos misericordia eius: et veritas Domini in aeternum.'' | ''O praise the LORD, all ye nations: praise him, all ye people.'' ''For his merciful kindness is great toward us: and the truth of the LORD endureth for ever.'' |} ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Nausicaa/347|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Nausicaa/349|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=376]]
==Annotations== '''''Omnis caro ad te veniet'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''All flesh shall come unto thee.''Gifford (1988) 415.
Thornton (1968) 329. See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Proteus/047|047.26-27]]. '''''omnipotentiam deiparae supplicem'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''a suppliant almightiness of the Mother of God'', or ''an almightiness of petition of the Mother of God''.Gifford (1988) 415.
Thornton (1968) 329-330. ''Omnipotentia supplex'' (''the all-powerful suppliant'') is an honorific title bestowed on the [[w:Mary (Mother of Jesus)|Virgin Mary]]. [[w:Bernardino of Siena|Saint Bernardino of Siena]] said of her: ''Mary has the keys of the divine treasury, so that she can distribute to whom she wills and as much as she wills, the grace of the Holy Spirit.''{{cite book |title=Mary's Praise on Every Tongue |last=Chandlery, S. J. |first=Peter Joseph |year=1910 |publisher=Manresa Press |location=London |page=46 |url=http://www.archive.org/stream/maryspraise00chanuoft#page/n67/mode/1up}} The preface of this book was written by Father Bernard Vaughan, S. J., who is mentioned in ''Ulysses'' ([[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Lotus_Eaters/079|079.05]] and [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Wandering_Rocks/211|211.08-09]]). The same point is made in the popular prayer ''[[w:Memorare|Memorare]]'', which is often attributed to [[w:Bernard of Clairvaux|Saint Bernard of Clairvaux]], but Stephen's phrase has not been found in any genuine work by Saint Bernard. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen_of_the_Sun/372|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen_of_the_Sun/374|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

page.title: Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen of the Sun/374

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=377]]
==Annotations== '''''vergine madre figlia di tuo figlio'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Italian'') ''virgin mother, daughter of your son'', a quotation from Dante's ''Paradiso'' (33.1). The words are spoken by St Bernard of Clairvaux in honour of the Virgin Mary. '''''parce que M. Leo Taxil nous a dit que qui l'avait mise dans cette fichue position c'était le sacré pigeon, ventre de Dieu!'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''Because Monsieur Léo Taxil has told us that it was the sacred pigeon who had placed her in this wretched position, by Christ!'' The final three words, which literally translate as ''belly of God!'', are a coarse French oath. See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Proteus/041|041.19]] ff. for Léo Taxil. '''''Entweder'' transsubstantiality ''oder'' consubstantiality but in no case subsubstantiality'''{{spaces|5}}(''German'') ''Either ... or.'' In Catholic theology, ''[[w:Transsubstantiation|transsubstantiation]]'' is the technical term to describe the principle underlying the doctrine of the [[w:Real presence of Christ in the Eucharist|Real Presence]], according to which the consecrated bread and wine in the Eucharist take on the actual [[w:Substance theory|substance]] of the body and blood of Jesus Christ, while retaining the outward appearance or accidence of bread and wine. ''[[w:Consubstantiation|Consubstanstiation]]'' is the term used to describe an alternative interpretation of the mystery of the Eucharist, according to which the consecrated bread and wine comprise the substance of Christ ''alongside'' that of the original unconsecrated bread and wine. The doctrine of consubstantiation is usually associated with [[w:Lutheranism|Lutheranism]], though [[w:Martin Luther|Martin Luther]] himself held a slightly different position. This, presumably, explains Stephen's use of German terms. Needless to remark, ''subsubstantiality'' is Stephen's drunken contribution to the theology of the Real Presence. In his intoxicated state, he is confusing two different theologial controversies: (1) the relationship between the consecrated Host in the[[w:Eucharist|Eucharist]] and Jesus Christ, and (2)the relationship between the [[w:Roman Catholic Mariology|Virgin Mary]] and Jesus Christ. According to Catholic doctrine, Mary was the mother of Jesus Christ the man and of Jesus Christ the God. this is also held by [[w:Lutheran marian theology|Lutherans]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen_of_the_Sun/373|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen_of_the_Sun/375|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

page.title: Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen of the Sun/375

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=378]]
==Annotations== '''''Ut novetur sexus omnis corporis mysterium'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''That the secret of the sex of every body may be known''.Gifford (1988) 417.
Thornton (1968) 331.
Bowen (1974) 242. Gifford translates this: ''That the whole mystery of physical sexuality may become known'', but Joyce seems to be talking about the determination of the sex (male or female) of the foetus. The title is possibly an allusion to a genuine anthem (or [[w:Antiphon|antiphon]]), ''O Redemptor sume carmen temet concinentium'' (''O Redeemer, Receive the Song of Those Who Celebrate Thee''), which includes the line: ''Ut novetur sexus omnis unctione Chrismatis'' (''That both men and women may be renewed by this chrism''). This hymn is sung on [[w:Maundy Thursday|Maundy Thursday]] in the [[w:Chrism|Mass of the Chrism]]. '''''Orate, fratres, pro memetipso'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Pray, Brethren, for me myself.''Gifford (1988) 418.
Thornton (1968) 332. These words are based on the [[w:Offertory|Offertory]] in the [[w:Tridentine Mass|Latin Tridentine Mass]], which was still in use in 1904. At the end of the Offertory, the celebrant kisses the altar, turns to the congregation and says: ''[[w:Orate fratres|Orate, fratres]]: ut meum ac vestrum sacrificium acceptabile fiat apud Deum patrem omnipotentem'' (''Pray, Brethren, that my and your sacrifice may be acceptable to God the Almighty Father'').[http://www.archive.org/stream/MissaleRomanum1603#page/n83/mode/1up ''Missale Romanum'' 83.] ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen_of_the_Sun/374|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen_of_the_Sun/376|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

page.title: Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen of the Sun/376

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=379]]
==Annotations== '''''ubi'' and ''quomodo'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''the where and the manner''.Gifford (1988) 420. '''''Etienne chanson'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''Stephen song''. Gabler emends this by inserting a comma after ''Etienne'' (required) and capitalizing ''chanson'' (not required). ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''

page.title: Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen of the Sun/382
Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen of the Sun/383
Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen of the Sun/384

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=387]]
==Annotations== '''''Talis ac tanta depravatio hujus seculi, O quirites, ut matres familiarum nostrae lascivas cujuslibet semiviri libici titillationes testibus ponderosis atque excelsis erectionibus centurionum Romanorum magnopere anteponunt'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Such and so great is the depravity of our generation, O Citizens, that our materfamiliases greatly prefer the lascivious titillations of any barbaric half-man whomsoever to the ponderous testicles and extraordinary erections of Roman centurions''.Gifford (1988) 427.
Thornton (1968) 338-339. Needless to say, this is not a quotation from the Classics, though the style is deliberately [[w:Cicero|Ciceronian]]. Mulligan's ''libici'' is problematic. Thornton translates it as ''lustful'', which would actually be ''libidinosi''. Gifford translates it as ''Gallic'', an allusion to the ''Libici'', a Gallic people;[http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus:text:1999.04.0059:entry=Libici&highlight=libici ''A Latin Dictionary''.] but ''Libicorum'' would be the correct form. In the first draft Joyce wrote ''Libycci'' (or ''Libyeci''), so his original intention seems clear: ''Libyci'' (''Libyan'', ''African'').[http://www.jstor.org/stable/20163489 R. J. Schork, ''Buck Mulligan as ''Grammaticus Gloriosus'' in Joyce's'' Ulysses.] The point of the passage is that Roman matrons prefer sexual satisfaction to conception: ''copulation without population'', another form of contraception, which is the interpretation Joyce puts on the slaughter of the Oxen of the Sun in this episode. Joyce was influenced here by an [[w:Epigram|epigram]] of [[w:Martial|Martial]]:[http://www.hs-augsburg.de/~harsch/Chronologia/Lspost01/Martialis/mar_ep06.html Martial, ''Epigrams'' 6:57.] {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''Epigrams'' 6:67''' |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ''Cur tantum eunuchos habeat tua Caelia, quaeris'' ''Pannyche? Vult futui Caelia nec parere.'' | ''Do you ask why your Caelia has only eunuchs,'' ''Pannychus? Caelia want to get fucked, not pregnant.'' |} In an earlier draft, Joyce used the word ''spadonis'' (''of a eunuch'') before replacing it with ''semiviri'' (''of a half-man'').[http://www.jstor.org/stable/20163489 R. J. Schork, ''op. cit.'' 87.] See also [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Circe/489|489.09]] for a reference to another Libyan eunuch. R. J. Schork renders the passage literally as: ''Such and so great is the depravity of this age, O fellow citizens, that our mothers of families greatly prefer the wanton titillations of some one or another half-male barbarian to the massive testicles and sky-high erections of Roman centurions''.[http://www.jstor.org/stable/20163489 R. J. Schork, ''op. cit.'' 82.] It has been suggested that the [[wikt:solecism|solecisms]] in this passage are intentional, to undermine Mulligan's pretensions to classical scholarship:[http://www.jstor.org/stable/20163518 Michele Valerie Ronnick, ''Buck Mulligan's Latin in "Ulysses"''.] :'''O quirites —''' In Latin, the vocative is not introduced by ''O''. :'''titillationes —''' In classical Latin, ''titillationes'' means ''ticklings''. :'''excelsis erectionibus —''' To a Roman, this would refer to tall buildings, not hardons. :'''centurionum Romanorum —''' In Classical Latin the noun ''centurio'' (''centurion'') is never qualified by the adjective ''Romanus''. :'''anteponunt —''' This should be the subjunctive ''anteponant''. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen_of_the_Sun/383|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen_of_the_Sun/385|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

page.title: Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen of the Sun/385
Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen of the Sun/386

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=389]]
==Annotations== '''''marchand de capotes'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''cloak merchant''. But ''capote'' is also slang for ''condom'', which provides the subtext of Alec Bannon's remarks.[http://www.cnrtl.fr/definition/capote '''Capote'''] '''''livre'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''pound''. The ''livre'' was an obsolete French coin originally representing the value of a pound of silver. By the time it was replaced by the franc, its value had dropped to less than that of five grammes of silver, or a little less than that of one franc. The word is now used to designate a pound Sterling.[http://www.cnrtl.fr/definition/livre '''Livre'''] '''Le Fécondateur'''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''The Fertilizer'', or ''The Impregnator''. Should this term be in italics? '''''avec lui'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''with him''. '''''ventre biche'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') A coarse oath. In French, ''ventre de Dieu'' (''God's belly!'') is an archaic oath. In order to avoid taking the holy name in vain, ''Dieu'' was either suppressed altogether or replaced with an innocuous word: ''Ventre!'' (''Belly!''), ''Ventre de loup!'' (''Wolf's belly!''), ''Ventre de boeuf!'' (''Bull's belly!''), ''Ventre de biche!'' (''Doe's belly!''). ''Ventre de biche'' is always the name of a colour (reddish-white, or a light beige). I have not come across Joyce's contraction of ''ventre de biche'', which may be an error.[http://www.cnrtl.fr/definition/ventre '''Ventre'''], [http://littre.reverso.net/dictionnaire-francais/definition/ventre '''Ventre'''] '''''sans blague'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''no kidding''. '''''il y a deux choses'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''there are two things''. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen_of_the_Sun/385|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen_of_the_Sun/387|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen of the Sun/391

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=394]]
==Annotations== '''''Sturzgeburt'''''{{spaces|5}}(''German'') ''sudden birth'', a term used in legal medicine to describe a precipitate deliveryin which the foetus falls out of the birth canal. Use of the term arises in cases where the foetus has been injured or killed during birth, either as a result of ''Sturzgeburt'' or through ill-treatment following delivery. The term is also used to describe any birth that occurs almost immediately after the onset of labour, with few contractions. '''''primafacie'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''[[wikt:prima facie|prima facie]]'' is a Latin expression meaning ''at first sight'', ''on the face of it''. In English it may be used as an adjective meaning ''obvious'', ''not requiring proof''. Hans Walter Gabler amended Joyce's ''primafacie'' to ''prima facie''.{{cite book |title=Ulysses: The Corrected Text |last=Joyce |first=James |editor=Hans Walter Gabler |others=With Wolfhard Steppe and Claus Melchior |year=1986 |publisher=The Bodley Head |location=London |page=336}} ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen_of_the_Sun/390|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen_of_the_Sun/392|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

page.title: Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen of the Sun/397

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=400]]
==Annotations== '''Div. Scep.'''{{spaces|5}}(''Dog Latin'') ''Divinitatis Scepticus'' or ''Doubter of Divinity'', a [[w:Dog Latin|mock Latin]] academic degree analogous to ''D. D.'' (''Divinitatis Doctor'', or ''[[w:Doctor of Divinity|Doctor of Divinity]]'').Gifford (1988) 436. In Latin, ''Scepticus'' was used in the plural (''Sceptici'') to denote the philosophical sect of [[w:Skepticism|Sceptics]], who doubted all things. '''Pubb. Canv.'''{{spaces|5}} ''Public Canvasser'', a mock academic degree describing Bloom's occupation (canvasser for advertisments).Gifford (1988) 436. The double ''bb'' suggests that Joyce is thinking of a [[w:Late Latin|Late Latin]] academic degree such as might have been conferred on a [[w:Scholasticism|Scolastic]] scholar. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen_of_the_Sun/396|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen_of_the_Sun/398|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

page.title: Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen of the Sun/398

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=401]]
==Annotations== '''''nisus formativus'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''formative tendency''.Gifford (1988) 437.
Thornton (1968) 344-345. This was [[w:Johann Friedrich Blumenbach|Johann Friedrich Blumenbach's]] term for the creative impulse (German: ''Bildungstrieb'') which he believed all living things possessed.{{cite book |title=Über den Bildungstrieb und das Zeugungsgeschäfte. |last=Blumenbach |first=Johann Friedrich |year=1781 |publisher=Johann Christian Dieterich, |location=Göttingen |url=http://gallery.mac.com/rbrisson#100008}} By attributing this to the spermatozoon, the author seems to be appropriating Blumenbach's term to describe [[w:Aristotle|Aristotle's]] theory that the semen or male principle determines the sex of the embryo: if the male principle prevails, the embryo becomes male; if the male principle is prevailed over, the embryo does not become male (i.e. a female embryo is one which was not made male).Aristotle, ''[http://ebooks.adelaide.edu.au/a/aristotle/generation/book4.html On the Generation of Animals'' 4.1.763b20-766b26.] '''''succubitus felix'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''the fertile one who has lain under [another]''.Gifford (1988) 437. If this were in the feminine (''succubita felix''), it could refer to a woman who has lain down passively in order to let a man mount her. However, the masculine gender and the context suggest that the expression actually refers to ''a happily chosen position''; ''[[wikt:felix|felix]]'' can mean ''happy''. This may allude to [[w:Aristotle|Aristotle's]] theory that the passive female element may prevail over the male during sexual intercourse (resulting in a female embryo) if, for example, the copulating creatures face north or south.Aristotle, ''[http://ebooks.adelaide.edu.au/a/aristotle/generation/book4.html On the Generation of Animals'' 4.2.767a8-12.] '''Hyg. et Eug. Doc.'''{{spaces|5}}''Doctor of Hygienics and Eugenics'', a mock academic degree describing Mulligan's present preoccupation with [[wikt:hygienics|hygienics]] and [[wikt:eugenics|eugenics]].Gifford (1988) 437. Like Stephen's mock degree, Mulligan's suggests a [[w:Dog Latin|Dog Latin]] adaptation of ''Divinitatis Doctor'' (''Doctor of Divinity''). '''Disc. Bacc.'''{{spaces|5}}(''Dog Latin'') ''Disciplinis Baccalaureus'', ''Bachelor of Discipline'', a [[w:Dog Latin|mock Latin]] academic degree analogous to ''B. A.'' (''Artium Baccalaureus'', or ''[[w:Bachelor of Arts|Bachelor of Arts]]'').Gifford (1988) 437. Gifford translates this as ''Bachelor of Discourse'', but in this section the degrees conferred on the graduates generally reflect the points they are making; Crotthers attributes the demise in the ''calibre of the race'' to ''discipline in the home''. '''Bacc. Arith.'''{{spaces|5}}(''Dog Latin'') ''Baccalaureus Arithmeticorum'', ''Bachelor of Arithmetic'', a [[w:Dog Latin|mock Latin]] academic degree analogous to ''B. A.'' (''Artium Baccalaureus'', or ''[[w:Bachelor of Arts|Bachelor of Arts]]'').Gifford (1988) 437. This particular degree is appropriate, as Lynch is proposing a ''law of numeration'' to account for everything. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen_of_the_Sun/397|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen_of_the_Sun/399|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

page.title: Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen of the Sun/399

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=402]]
==Annotations== '''Div. Scep.'''{{spaces|5}}See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Oxen_of_the_Sun/397|397.25]]. '''Pubb. Canv.'''{{spaces|5}}See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Oxen_of_the_Sun/397|397.31]]. '''Lic. in Midw., F. K. Q. C. P. I.'''{{spaces|5}}''Licensed in Midwifery, Fellow of the King and Queen's College of Physicians of Ireland''.Gifford (1988) 438. In ''Thom's 1904'', Andrew John Horne is described as "ex-Vice-Pres. Royal College of Physicians, Ireland." He was also an examiner in [[wikt:midwifery|midwifery]] and F.R.C.P.I (''Fellow of the Royal College of Physicians in Ireland'').''Thom's Official Directory of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland for the Year 1904'' (Dublin, 1904), p. 1381 and p. 865. Gifford renders F.K.Q.C.P.I as ''Former Knight of the Queen's College of Physicians in Ireland'', believing that Joyce was thinking of Horne's status as ''ex-Vice-President'' of the College. However, on 15 Decdember 1692 the college was reincorporated by the coregents [[w:William and Mary|William and Mary]], after which it was known as the ''King and Queen's College of Physicians in Ireland''; in 1890, under charter of Queen Victoria, it adopted its present title. '''''accouchement'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''delivery'' (i.e. the act of giving birth). Like ''enceinte'' (''pregnant''), this term has become a naturalized English euphemism. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen_of_the_Sun/398|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen_of_the_Sun/400|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

page.title: Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen of the Sun/400

revision.comment:

page.title: Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen of the Sun/401

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=404]]
==Annotations== '''''flair'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''intuition'', ''perspicacity'', ''instinctive understanding''. The word is, of course, also an English expression, but I am assuming that Joyce's use of italics implies that this is a foreign term. Walter Pater, whose style is being parodied in this section, was fond of including numerous italicized foreign words in his prose, especially in his early work. '''''piazzetta'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Italian'') ''a small veranda''. Properly, ''piazzetta'' means ''a small square in a city'', being a diminutive of ''piazza''. The latter, however, can refer to the veranda of a house, which seems to be what is required here. '''''alles vergängliche'''''{{spaces|5}}(''German'') ''all that is transitory''. These are the opening words of the final chorus in Goethe's drama ''Faust'', Part II (1832): {| !
Chorus Mysticus
!
Mystical Chorus
|- | style="padding-right: 6em;" | :::''Alles Vergängliche :::''ist nur ein Gleichnis;'' :::''das Unzulängliche, '' :::''hier wird's Ereignis;'' :::''das Unbeschreibliche,'' :::''hier ist es getan; '' :::''das Ewigweibliche'' :::''zieht uns hinan.'' | style="padding-left: 3em;" | :::All that is transitory :::Is only a parable; :::The insufficient, :::Here it comes to pass; :::The indescribable, :::Here it is accomplished; :::The Eternal Feminine :::Draws us upwards. |} ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen_of_the_Sun/400|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen_of_the_Sun/402|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

page.title: Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen of the Sun/402
Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen of the Sun/403

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=406]]
==Annotations== '''''Deine Kuh Truebsal melkest Du. Nun trinkst Du die suesse Milch des Euters'''''{{spaces|5}}(''German'') ''You are milking your cow "Affliction". Now you are drinking the sweet milk of her udder.'' The words are not spoken by Zarathustra in Nietzsche's ''Also Sprach Zarathustra''. Weldon Thornton notes a similarity to Shakespeare: ''Adversity's sweet milk, philosophy'' (''Romeo and Juliet'' 3:3:55). '''''Per deam Partulam et Pertundam nunc est bibendum !'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''By the goddess Partula and Pertunda now we must drink''.Gifford (1988) 441.
Thornton (1968) 348. [[w:Partula_(goddess)|Partula]], or Parca, was a Roman goddess of childbirth. Pertunda was a Roman goddess of sexual intercourse and carnal love who presided over the loss of virginity; she has been identified with [[w:Juno_(mythology)|Juno]]; he name derives from ''pertundere'' (''to penetrate''). ''Nunc est bibendum'' (''Now is the time to drink'') are the opening words of [[w:Horace|Horace's]] ''[[w:Odes_(Horace)|Odes]]'' 1.37, written to celebrate [[w:Augustus|Octavian's]] victory over [[w:Mark Antony|Antony]] and [[w:Cleopatra_VII|Cleopatra]].[http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.02.0025%3Abook%3D1%3Apoem%3D37 Horace, ''Odes'' 1.37.] '''''Benedicat vos omnipotens Deus, Pater et Filius'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''May almighty God bless you, Father and Son''.Gifford (1988) 441.
Thornton (1968) 348. In the [[w:Tridentine Mass|Latin Tridentine Mass]], which was still in use in 1904, the [[w:Dismissal_(liturgy)|Dismissal]] ends with the [[w:Priestly_Blessing|Blessing]], ''Benedicat vos omnipotens Deus, Pater et Filius et Spiritus Sanctus'' (''May almighty God bless you, Father and Son and Holy Spirit''), to which the congregation replies ''Amen''. There then follows the [[w:Last Gospel|Last Gospel]].[http://www.archive.org/stream/missaleromanume01churgoog#page/n459/mode/1up ''Missale Romanum'' 339.] '''''En avant, mes enfants!'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''Forward, my children!'' '''''Ma mère m'a mariée'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''My mother married me''. These are the opening words of a bawdy French song: {| !
French
!
English
|- | style="padding-right: 6em;" | :::''Ma mère m'a mariée un mari. :::''Mon Dieu, quel homme, qu'il est petit!'' :::''Je l'ai perdu au fond de mon lit.'' :::''Mon Dieu, quel homme, qu'il est petit!'' :::''Etc.'' | style="padding-left: 3em;" | :::My mother married me off to a husband. :::My God, what a man, how small he is! :::I lost him at the bottom of my bed. :::My God, what a man, how small he is! :::Etc. |} '''''Retamplan Digidi Boum Boum'''''{{spaces|5}}Nonsense words believed to represent the sound of drums. In French, ''rataplan'' is commonly used to express the sound of a drum, especially in marching songs. ''Boum Boum'' could be an improvised French spelling of ''Boom Boom'', the English equivalent of ''rataplan''. Gabler reverts to the manuscript reading: ''Retamplatan digidi boumboum''. '''''Silentium !'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Silence!''Gifford (1988) 442. '''''Uebermensch'''''{{spaces|5}}(''German'') See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce%27s_Ulysses/Telemachus/022|022.16]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen_of_the_Sun/402|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen_of_the_Sun/404|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

page.title: Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen of the Sun/404

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=407]]
==Annotations== '''''Caramba!'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Spanish'') ''Good grief!'' A Spanish exclamation of shock, surprise, anger or vexation. But the word ''caramba'' is a euphemism for the vulgar ''carajo'' (''penis''). '''''Merci'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''Thank you''. '''''Les petites femmes'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''Little women''. This term was used to allude to women of loose virtue.[http://www.cnrtl.fr/definition/femme CNRTL: '''femme'''] '''''Ex !'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Out!'' In the context of the bawdy version of the ''Eton Boat Song'', this possibly refers to ''[[w:Coitus interruptus|coitus interruptus]]'', a method on contraception in which the man withdraws his penis from a woman's vagina prior to ejaculation, which takes place ''ex copula'' (''outside of sexual union''). '''''ad lib.'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''to whatever extent''; ''without restriction''. An abbreviated form of ''[[wikt:ad libitum|ad libitum]]''. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen_of_the_Sun/403|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen_of_the_Sun/405|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

page.title: Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen of the Sun/405

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=408]]
==Annotations== '''''Nos omnes biberimus viridum toxicum diabolus capiat posterioria nostria'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Dog Latin'') ''We will all drink green poison [and] the devil take the hindmost''.Gifford (1988) 446.
Thornton (1968) 354. The ''green poison'' is [[w:Absinthe|absinthe]], which Stephen referred to earlier in the day as ''green fairy'' ([[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Proteus/043|043.02]]), a name by which it is known in France. ''[[wikt:devil take the hindmost|The devil take the hindmost]]'' is a common expression. ''Posterioria nostria'' is not real Latin, though the meaning (''our posteriors'') is clear. Presumably this comment is added by Mulligan after Stephen has ordered absinthe for everyone; Mulligan's Latin, unlike Stephen's, is not always correct ([[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Oxen_of_the_Sun/384|384.15-18]]) and he has been preoccupied with posteriors before ([[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Scylla_and_Charybdis/192|192.36 ff.]] and [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Scylla_and_Charybdis/197|197.13]]). '''''Bonsoir la compagnie'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''Goodnight, everyone''. This is the title of a French song by the Abbé Gabriel Charles de L'Attaignant. The words were subsequently translated into English by Edwin Arnold and set to new music by Constance Maud (1896). The significance of the expression is that it is closing time and Mulligan, who is trying to give Stephen the slip, is taking [[wikt:French leave|French leave]]. '''''A la vôtre!'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''Cheers!'' Gabler restores the grave accent to the first word, but in French accents are often omitted from uppercase letters. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen_of_the_Sun/404|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen_of_the_Sun/406|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

page.title: Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen of the Sun/406

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=409]]
==Annotations== '''''Tiens, tiens'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''Indeed? Well, well.'' An interjection expressing surprise, doubt, disapproval, or skepticism. '''''Laetabuntur in cubilibus suis'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''They shall rejoice in their beds''.Gifford (1988) 449.
Thornton (1968) 356. This is an adaptation of Psalms 149:5:[http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Psalms%20149&version=VULGATE Psalms 149.] {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''Psalms 149:5''''' |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ''Exultabunt sancti in gloria; laudabunt in cubilibus suis.'' | ''The saints shall exult in glory: they shall praise in their beds.'' |} '''''Ut implerentur scripturae'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''That the scriptures might be fulfilled''.Gifford (1988) 449.
Thornton (1968) 356-357. This phrase occurs once in the [[w:Vulgate|Latin Vulgate]] translation of the Bible: Matthew 26:56, in which Jesus is arrested in the Garden of Gethsemane:[http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Matthaeus+26:55-57&version=VULGATE Matthew 26:55-57.] {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''Matthew 26:56''''' |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ''Hoc autem totum factum est ut implerentur scripturae prophetarum. Tunc discipuli omnes relicto eo fugerunt.'' | ''But all this was done, that the scriptures of the prophets might be fulfilled. Then all the disciples forsook him, and fled.'' |} ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen_of_the_Sun/405|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Oxen_of_the_Sun/407|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

revision.text:
==Satire?== It's fun to read ''Avoid stereotypes and Generalizations'' and then to proceed with countless stereotypes and generalizations. Most of them are unreferenced, many copied from an old version from Wikipedia (which has since been cleaned up a little bit) or added later without any proof. The list of references is way too short and even contains indistinguishable entries – duplicates, actually, but they would benefit from page references. --[[User:Zahnradzacken|Zahnradzacken]] ([[User talk:Zahnradzacken|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Zahnradzacken|contribs]]) 15:45, 27 November 2011 (UTC)
== I propose extending this to all nations == This would mean changing the title to something like "International Guide of Etiquette"
China *It is good etiquette to strongly refuse gifts. *Gifting a wall-clock has associations is taken as a worming about infidelity in the receiving couple. *Never gift flowers, they are associated with funerals (death). --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Panic2k4|contribs]]) 19:51, 10 October 2013 (UTC)

== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Funkjoker23!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks. --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Italy.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 17:59, 27 November 2011 (UTC)

page.title: Lentis/Implementation of Technology in Sports: Historical Successes and Failures, and Modern Discussion

revision.comment: Removing "Jacques_Plante_donning_the_mask.jpg", it has been deleted from Commons by [[commons:User:Fastily|Fastily]] because: No license since 6 December 2011.
revision.text:
Factors at the interface of society and technology influence technological advancements in sports. Three separate technologies, hockey goalie masks, performance-enhancing drugs, and fantasy sports, generated controversies when first introduced. Yet, one became a success while another failed entirely. The success of the third has yet to be determined. This chapter will examine the causes for success or failure to generalize a lesson about technology in sports.
=The Evolution of Hockey Masks=
Modern hockey goaltenders rely on form-fitting fiberglass composite masks to protect their face and skull from frozen pucks of vulcanized rubber traveling at speeds up to 100 mph. "I can't imagine going out there without a mask," said [[w:New York Rangers|New York Rangers]] goalie [[w:Martin Biron|Martin Biron]]. "Getting pucks shot at you… or a skate or a stick. As a goalie, you’ve got these scrums in front of the net… that would just be unbelievable<ref name="Roarke">Roarke, Shawn P. Playing without a mask unthinkable to today’s goalies. http://www.nhl.com/ice/news.htm?id=503855 </ref>.”
National Hockey League referees stop play when goalkeepers lose their facemask, unless there is a clear scoring opportunity<ref> NHL/ IIHF Rules Comparison. http://www.nhl.com/ice/page.htm?id=60036 </ref>. Yet, prior the 1959-1960 NHL season, masks were almost unheard of in the league. Traditionalists thought masks detracted from the purism of the game. Chico Resch, longtime NHL goaltender and commentator, grew up watching pre-facemask era goalies and described them as “the most courageous athletes ever<ref name="Roarke" />."
Men like Andy Brown, the last goalie to play without a mask, embraced this fearless image. Others suffered like Glenn Hall, who vomited before games and between periods, continuously contemplating retirement. “I sometimes ask myself ‘what the hell am I doing out here,” he said. He wasn't alone. Frank McCool and Roger Crozier developed ulcers, while [[w:Terry Sawchuk|Terry Sawchuk]] became depressed and abused alcohol<ref name= "Hynes">Hynes, Jim, Gary Smith. Saving Face: The Art and History of the Goalie Mask. 2008 </ref>.
==Early Introductions==
Early 1920's era goaltender's masks originated from contemporary fencing or baseball catcher’s masks introduced 50 years prior. Photographs show a goaltender in Switzerland wearing a catcher-style mask, while other sources indicate Elizabeth Graham of the Queen’s University hockey team wore a fencing mask at her father's behest<ref name= "Hynes" />. Masks became popular amongst amateurs, but NHL goalies still refused to wear them for fear of perceived weakness. [[w:Clint Benedict|Clint Benedict]] became the first NHL player to wear a mask after badly breaking his nose in 1930, but discarded it just five games later. 29 years would pass before full time masks became a fixture in the league.
==Jacques Plante==
Montrealer Bill Burchmore began experimenting with molded facemasks in late 1958. The following year, on November 1, 1959, a rising shot struck Montreal Canadiens goaltender [[w:Jacques Plante|Jacques Plante]] in the face,knocking him to the ice and requiring seven stitches. Plante, who had worked with Burchmore the previous summer to develop a practice mask, refused to return to the ice without it. Coach [[w:Toe Blake|Toe Blake]], with no replacement, had to comply. <ref name= "Hynes" /> Despite Blake’s protests, Plante's mask stayed and the Canadiens won 18 consecutive games.
==The Painted Mask and Perceptions Today==
Goalie masks remained controversial until the 1970s. Traditionalists saw the white, haunting masks as an insult to the game. This perception changed when [[w:Gerry Cheevers|Gerry Cheevers]] of the [[w:Boston Bruins|Boston Bruins]] tried to leave practice following a puck strike to his mask. Unimpressed, the coach ordered Cheevers back to the ice and the team trainer, in jest, painted stitches on the mask where the puck had struck. The stitch painting became tradition; Cheevers would add more stitches after each impact. Soon goalies all over the league painted designs on their masks to intimidate opponents, display nicknames, or advertise pop culture preferences. The artwork grew more complex and fans even began voting on their favorite designs. Over the course of a few years, painting transformed goalie masks from an affront to the league to a beloved part of the game.
=Steroids and Sports Enhancing Drugs=
==Early History== Performance enhancement originated in Ancient Greece when Olympic athletes consumed sheep testicles in the hopes of improving their athletic abilities <ref> Kopera, H. The history of anabolic steroids and a review of clinical experience with anabolic steroids. 2009. </ref> <ref> Kochakian, Charles. History of Anabolic-Androgenic Steroids. 2004. </ref>. While it is doubtful these athletes and trainers knew the exact effects of testicle consumption, their actions jumpstarted the steroid age.
==Modern Implementation== The true steroid era began in 1931 with German chemists [[w:Adolf Butenandt|Adolf Butenandt]] and [[w:Leopold Ruzicka|Leopold Ruzicka]], who purified and synthesized the hormone andosterone <ref> The Nobel Prize in Chemistry 1939. http://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/chemistry/laureates/1939/ </ref>. Both Nobel Prize winning scientists were under the direction of Adolf Hitler, developing chemical compounds to improve Nazi soldiers’ stamina and ferocity on the battlefield <ref> Beamish, Rob. Steroids: A New Look at Performance Enhancing Drugs. 2011. </ref>.
The Soviet Union took advantage of the German research by injecting their Olympic athletes with [[w:testosterone propionate|testosterone propionate]] in the 1940s. The Soviet Olympic successes and perceived athletic superiority became effective Cold War propaganda tools <ref> Howell, Reet. The USSR: Sport and Politics Intertwined. 1975. http://www.jstor.org/pss/3097941 </ref>. Initial U.S. reluctance to use steroids, due to negative health concerns, dissipated after [[w:John Bosley Ziegler|John Bosley Ziegler]] developed methandrostenolone <ref> Fair, John. 1993. Isometrics or Steroids? Exploring New Frontiers Of Strength in the Early 1960s. Journal of Sport History, (20)1. </ref>. The FDA approved and mass produced hormone helped the U.S. Olympians close the medal gap and contributed to society’s acceptance of anabolic steroids.
==Opposition== By 1967, steroid use was common among Olympic athletes. Athletes enjoyed reaching personal milestones, while fans appreciated the entertainment provided by these impressive feats. Steroids were perceived as a catalyst for competition. However, scientific doubts about steroid effectiveness <ref> Wade, N. 1972. Anabolic steroids: doctors denounce them, but athletes aren’t listening. Science 176, 1399–1403. </ref> coupled with negative health side effects led the [[w:International Olympic Committee|International Olympic Committee]] (IOC) to implement full-scale drug testing programs in 1972 <ref> The International Olympic Committee. http://www.olympic.org/about-ioc-institution?tab=mission </ref>. In addition, the Anti-Drug Abuse Act and the Steroid Control Act were passed to limit the legal use of anabolic steroids <ref> Parents. The Anti-Drug. http://www.theantidrug.com/ei/resources.asp </ref>.
A public backlash against athletes using steroids started in the late 1980’s. The first major steroid scandal occurred when Canadian sprinter [[w:Ben Johnson (sprinter)|Ben Johnson (sprinter)]] defeated heavily favored [[w:Carl Lewis|Carl Lewis]] in the 1988 Olympic Games, only to have his medal revoked for testing positive for anabolic steroids <ref> 1988: Johnson stripped of Olympic gold. http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/september/27/newsid_2539000/2539525.stm </ref>. This was only the first of numerous controversial cases involving the illegal use of steroids in sports, others including:
•Jose Conseco, MLB player •Marion Jones, track and field Olympian •Roger Clemons, MLB player •Lance Armstrong, cyclist •Alex Rodriguez, MLB player •Tiger Woods, PGA golfer
The steroid debate may have been most controversial in Major League Baseball. Fans were riveted in 1998 by the home run race between [[w:Mark McGwire|Mark McGwire]] and [[w:Sammy Sosa|Sammy Sosa]]. MLB TV viewership soared <ref> Ham, E. Broadcasting Baseball: A History of the National Pastime on Radio and Television. 2011 </ref> as fans watched these sluggers surpass Roger Marris’ single season home run record, and again when Barry Bonds broke McGuire's record a few years later. Yet the glory accrued by these home run kings was later tainted by accusations of steroid abuse. Fellow players, fans, and officials discredited their achievements <ref> The Mitchell Report. http://files.mlb.com/mitchrpt.pdf </ref>, signifying a prominent change in society’s opinion of steroids.
==Why Steroids Failed== Anabolic steroids started as a medical technology that was perceived to have a positive influence on athletic performances and sporting entertainment. However, a distinct change of opinion occurred when society realized that steroids were ruining the sacredness of sports. Fans felt betrayed and cheated. How could they support the achievements of steroid-abusing athletes, who belittled achievements by athletes unaided by chemical enhancements? Most fans became critical of the shortcuts these athletes took to succeed, devaluing its inherent entertainment. Society showed through its backlash to steroids that it cherished pure achievement over fake accomplishments. It was at this time the asterisk became a symbol of the steroid era – a symbol of the conditional, the undeserved, and the unreal. It showed that sporting accomplishments achieved with steroids had no place in sports history, and that the implementation of this medical technology was unsuccessful.
=The Success and Controversy of Fantasy Sports= ==Background== [[w:Fantasy sports|Fantasy sports]] allow everyday people to be team owners, drafting and managing their rosters while accumulating points based on players’ actual performance. A multibillion dollar industry <ref> Dorman, Stephen. The fantasy football phenomenon. 2006. http://www.theacorn.com/news/2006-08-03/Sports/076.html </ref>, the [[w:Fantasy Sports Trade Association |Fantasy Sports Trade Association ]] estimates 35 million adults play in the United States alone <ref> http://www.fsta.org/ </ref>.
The growth of fantasy sports has paralleled that of the Internet. Online media outlets like Yahoo! Sports and ESPN.com are among the largest free providers. Internet accessing mobile smart phones have increased avenues for playing. Even social networking sites like Twitter are getting involved through the launch of sites like STAT.US. The service includes a “Fantasy Tracker” that sends fantasy owners live stats and updates regarding their players via Tweets <ref> 30 November 2011. http://www.fsta.org/blog/fsta-press-release </ref>.
==Fantasy Sports in Society== Fantasy sports are largely protected under the law. The Unlawful Internet Gambling Enforcement Act of 2006 exempts fantasy sports on the premise that they are based on skill, not chance <ref> Rose, Nelson. Implementation of the Unlawful Internet Gambling Enforcement Act. 2008. http://www.gamblingandthelaw.com/articles/255-implementation-of-the-unlawful-internet-gambling-enforcement-act.html </ref>. Other court decisions have allowed the use of real-time wireless statistical distribution <ref> NBA v. Motorola and STATS, Inc. http://legal.web.aol.com/decisions/dldecen/nba.html </ref> and upheld fantasy providers’ right to athletes’ biographical information <ref> Voris, Bob V. and St. Onge, Jeff. Fantasy Sports Win Right to Player Names, Statistics. 16 October 2007. http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aVMAY0beLSoA&refer=home </ref>.
Fantasy sports have had pronounced effects on American fan culture. Fans are more likely to watch sports on television and attend games once becoming fantasy owners <ref> CDM Legal Victory in Appeals Court Ensures Continued Fantasy Sports Growth. 17 October 2007. http://fsta.org/news/pressreleases/CBCvsMLBAM.doc?PHPSESSID=glao8etoobku1pu8q98hln9262 </ref>. Fantasy sports have also connected Americans to international sports. English Premiere League soccer league and the Olympics, for instance, have fantasy leagues available to Americans. Socially, fantasy sports promote camaraderie via competitive, yet friendly, rivalries between league owners. The mainstream hit television comedy series, [[w:The League|The League]], demonstrates this phenomenon, encapsulating the lives of six friends engaged in an intensely competitive fantasy football league <ref> http://www.fxnetwork.com/shows/originals/theleague/aboutTheShow.php </ref>. Fantasy sports have even transcended into the American workplace. Michael Henby’s informational book, Fantasy Kick, illustrates his theories and testimonies that fantasy sports elevate networking abilities and enhance career opportunities <ref> Henby, Michael. Fantasy Kick. 2006 </ref>.
==Emerging Controversy== Fantasy sports have also been marked by controversy. Addiction to fantasy sports have led to the formation of social groups such as Women Against Fantasy Sports (WAFS), a website for women to bond over their loved ones' obsessions with fantasy sports <ref> Ervin, Kathleen A. Women Against Fantasy Sports. http://failuremag.com/index.php/feature/article/women_against_fantasy_sports/ </ref>.
A 2008 ESPN article featured the conflicting perspectives of several NFL athletes on fantasy football. Some players appreciated the ability of fantasy sports to bring athletes and fans together. Others, like former Broncos quarterback Jake Plummer think fantasy football has “ruined the game,” encouraging fans to root for fantasy rather than hometown rosters. Fantasy sports may even affect athletes' on field performance due to pressure from fantasy owners via letters and personal encounters. For Ladanian Tomlinson, this pressure can be motivating, explaining top fantasy draft picks “take pride and want to uphold that honor that someone has drafted you that high <ref name = "ESPN"> Garber, Greg. Fantasy craze produces awkward moments for players. 6 December 2006. http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/columns/story?columnist=garber_greg&id=2684942 </ref>." In 2007, ESPN.com even inducted athletes with high fantasy value into the Fantasy Football Hall of Fame, a further testament to the incentive fantasy sports provide athletes <ref> De Fino, Nando. Selecting the Cream of the Fantasy Crop. 15 January 2009. http://online.wsj.com/article/SB123187746819378309.html </ref>. The question remains, do fantasy sports tarnish the purity of the game? Several professional athletes, like [[w:Cato June|Cato June]] and [[w:Chris Cooley|Chris Cooley]], admit to playing fantasy sports. Does this, even subconsciously, affect an athlete’s performance <ref name="ESPN"/>? Questions like these will continue to be asked as fantasy sports gain widespread popularity and become engrained in our culture.
=Conclusion=
As the above cases illustrated, technology can improve athletes' performances, increase safety, and enhance fan experience. The success (or failure) of newly introduced technologies have largely been determined by their impact on the purity of the game. Hockey masks prevailed because the painted designs provided a new avenue for tradition without compromising the integrity of the game. On the other hand, performance enhancing drugs failed completely because they caused an environment of distrust that tarnished the reputations of athletes and some sports. Fantasy sports have developed a following, but not without controversy. These concerns will govern the future success of this cultural and technological phenomena.

== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, El-GoharyKM!

==Assumptions== *[[0.999.../Decimal long division|Decimal long division]] *[[0.999.../Decimal multiplication by a small number|Decimal multiplication by a small number]]
==Proof== Using long division, {{nowrap|1={{frac|1|3}} = 0.333…}}. Multiplying both sides by 3, we have {{nowrap|1=1 = 3 × 0.333… = 0.999…}}.
[[Category:0.999...|Proof from 0.333...]]

==Assumptions== *[[0.999.../Decimal long division|Decimal long division]] *[[0.999.../Decimal multiplication by a small number|Decimal multiplication by a small number]]
==Proof== Using long division, {{nowrap|1={{frac|1|9}} = 0.111…}}. Multiplying both sides by 9, we have {{nowrap|1=1 = 9 × 0.111… = 0.999…}}. Furthermore, because <sup>x</sup>/<sub>x</sub>=1, <sup>9</sup>/<sub>9</sub>=1. However, <sup>1</sup>/<sub>9</sub>=0.111..., so multiplying the numerator by nine, and thereby multiplying the answer by nine, produces 0.999... in terms of decimals, but, in terms of fractions, a numerator that is equal to the denominator.
[[Category:0.999...|Proof from 0.111...]]
{{Allbooks category}}

==Assumptions== *[[0.999.../Definition from series|Definition from series]] *[[0.999.../The geometric series formula|The geometric series formula]]
==Proof== Using the series definition of the value of an infinite decimal,
:<math>0.999\ldots = 9\left(\tfrac{1}{10}\right) + 9\left({\tfrac{1}{10}}\right)^2 + 9\left({\tfrac{1}{10}}\right)^3 + \cdots.\,</math>
This is a geometric series with a common ratio of 1/10. Applying the geometric series formula,
:<math>0.999\ldots = 9\left(\tfrac{1}{10}\right) + 9\left({\tfrac{1}{10}}\right)^2 + 9\left({\tfrac{1}{10}}\right)^3 + \cdots = \frac{9\left({\tfrac{1}{10}}\right)}{1-{\tfrac{1}{10}}} = 1.\,</math>
[[Category:0.999...|Proof by the geometric series formula]]
{{Allbooks category}}
{{Allbooks category}}
{{Allbooks category}}

==Assumptions== *[[0.999.../Definition from sequences|Definition from sequences]] *[[0.999.../Term-by-term operations on sequences|Term-by-term operations on sequences]] *[[0.999.../The limit of a geometric sequence|The limit of a geometric sequence]]
==Proof== :<math>0.999\ldots = \lim_{n\to\infty}0.\underbrace{ 99\ldots9 }_{n} = \lim_{n\to\infty}\sum_{k = 1}^n\frac{9}{10^k} = \lim_{n\to\infty}\left(1-\frac{1}{10^n}\right) = 1-\lim_{n\to\infty}\frac{1}{10^n} = 1.\,</math>
[[Category:0.999...|Proof by limit manipulation]]

==Assumptions== *[[0.999.../Definition from nested intervals|Definition from nested intervals]]
==Proof== Applying the nested-intervals definition of the value of an infinite decimal, 0.999... is the unique real number that lies in all of the intervals [0, 1], [0.9, 1], [0.99, 1], and [0.99...9, 1] for every finite string of 9s. Since 1 is an element of each of these intervals, 0.999... = 1.
[[Category:0.999...|Proof by nested intervals]]

revision.text:
==Assumptions== *[[0.999.../Construction of the real numbers from Dedekind cuts|Construction of the real numbers from Dedekind cuts]] *[[0.999.../Definition from Dedekind cuts|Definition from Dedekind cuts]]
==Proof== In the Dedekind cut approach, the real number 1 is the set of all rational numbers that are less than 1. Meanwhile, the real number 0.999... is the set of rational numbers ''r'' such that ''r'' < 0, or ''r'' < 0.9, or ''r'' < 0.99, or ''r'' is less than some other number of the form :<math>\begin{align}1-\left(\tfrac{1}{10}\right)^n\end{align}</math>. Every element of 0.999... is less than 1, so it is an element of the real number 1. Conversely, an element of 1 is a rational number :<math>\begin{align}\tfrac{a}{b}<1\end{align},</math> which implies :<math>\begin{align}\tfrac{a}{b}<1-\left(\tfrac{1}{10}\right)^b\end{align}.</math> Since 0.999... and 1 contain the same rational numbers, they are the same set: 0.999... = 1.
[[Category:0.999...|Proof by equality of Dedekind cuts]]

==Assumptions== *[[0.999.../Construction of the real numbers from Cauchy sequences|Construction of the real numbers from Cauchy sequences]] *[[0.999.../Definition from Cauchy sequences|Definition from Cauchy sequences]] *[[0.999.../The limit of a geometric sequence|The limit of a geometric sequence]]
==Proof== In this formalism the task is to show that the sequence of rational numbers :<math>\left(1 - 0, 1 - {9 \over 10}, 1 - {99 \over 100}, \dots\right) = \left(1, {1 \over 10}, {1 \over 100}, \dots \right)</math>
has the limit 0.
[[Category:0.999...|Proof by equivalence of Cauchy sequences]]
